(c)  Terms not defined. Where terms are not defined through the methods authorized by the codes, such terms shall have ordinarily accepted meanings such as the context implies. 
(Code 1997, § 4-2-101; Ord. No. 2006-37, 8-27-2006)  
Sec. 8-47. - Board of adjustments and appealsEstablished; members. 
There is hereby created the city board of adjustments and appeals for new construction and property maintenance hereafter known as the "board." 
(1)  Members. The mayor of the city shall appoint a minimum of three members who are qualified by experience and training to pass on matters pertaining to new construction and property maintenance and who are not employees of the city. The code official shall be an ex officio member but shall have no vote on any matter before the board. The board shall serve staggered and overlapping terms. 
(2)  Chairperson. The board shall annually select one of its members to serve as chairperson. 
(3)  Conflict of interest. A member shall not hear an appeal in which that member has a personal, professional or financial interest. 
(4)  Secretary. The city manager shall designate a qualified person to serve as secretary to the board. The secretary shall file a detailed record of all proceedings in the office of the city manager. 
(5)  Removal of board members. The mayor may remove any member for failure to attend three consecutive meetings or for failure to attend a majority of meetings in a 12-month period, or for cause. 
(Code 1997, § 4-2-102; Ord. No. 2006-37, 8-27-2006)  
Sec. 8-48. - SameAppeals. 
(a)  Application for appeal. Any person directly affected by a decision of the code official or a notice or order issued under the city building codes and property maintenance codes shall have the right to appeal to the board, provided that a written application for appeal is filed within 20 days (five days for weeds and grass) after the day the decision, notice or order was served. An application for appeal shall be based on a claim that the true intent of the code provisions or the rules legally adopted there under have been incorrectly interpreted, the provisions of the code do not fully apply, the requirements of the code are adequately satisfied by other means, or than the strict application of any requirement of the code would cause an undue hardship. 
(b)  Notice of meeting. The board shall meet upon notice from the chairperson or at stated periodic meetings but, in no event, later than 20 days following notice of an appeal. 
(c)  Hearing. The appellant, the appellant's representative, the code official and any person whose interests are affected shall be given an opportunity to be heard. A quorum shall consist of not less than two-thirds of the board's membership. 
(d)  Procedure. The board shall adopt and make available to the public, through the secretary, procedures governing the conduct of a hearing. The procedures shall not require compliance with strict rules of evidence but shall mandate that only relevant information be received. 
(e)  Board decision. The board shall modify or reverse the decision of the code official only by a concurring vote of a majority of the total number of board members present. 
(f)  Records and copies. The decision of the board shall be recorded. Copies shall be furnished to the appellant and to the code official. 
(g)  Administration. The code official shall take immediate action in accordance with the decision of the board. 
(h)  Stays of enforcement. Appeals of notice and orders of the code official to the board (other than imminent danger notices) shall stay the enforcement of the notice and order until the appeal is heard by the appeals board. 
(i)  Court review. Any person, whether or not a previous party to the appeal, shall have the right to apply to the appropriate court for a writ of certiorari from the decision of the board. Application for review shall be made in the manner and time required by law following the filing of the decision in the office of the city manager. 
(Code 1997, § 4-2-103; Ord. No. 2006-37, 8-27-2006)  
Sec. 8-49. - SameAuthority. 
(a)  The board is hereby designated as the board of adjustments and appeals for the following codes: 
(1)  International Residential Code. 
(2)  International Building Code and appendixes. 
(3)  International Existing Building Code. 
(4)  International Energy Conservation Code. 
(5)  International Fuel Gas Code. 
(6)  International Mechanical Code. 
(7)  International Fire Code. 
(8)  Life Safety National Fire Protection Association 101 Code. 
(9)  International Swimming Pool Code. 
(10)  International Property Maintenance Code. 
(11)  International Plumbing Code. 
(12)  International Residential Plumbing Code. 
(13)  1999 NC Accessibility Code. 
(14)  Chapter 22, pertaining to stormwater. 
(b)  The following provisions from the codes listed in subsection (a) of this section, adopted by reference pursuant to the ordinance from which this article is derived are amended as follows: 
(1)  International Building Code. Delete section B101, appendix B, board of appeals. 
(2)  International Property Maintenance Code. Delete section 111 means of appeal. 
(3)  International Residential Code. Delete section R112, board of appeals. 
(4)  International Plumbing Code. Delete section 109, means of appeal. 
(5)  International Fuel Gas Code. Delete section 109, (IFGC) means of appeal. 
(6)  International Fire Code. Delete section 108, board of appeals. 
(7)  International Existing Building Code. Delete section 112, board of appeals. 
(8)  International Mechanical Code. Delete section 109, means of appeal. 
(Code 1997, § 4-2-104; Ord. No. 2006-37, 8-27-2006)  
Sec. 8-50. - Code amendments not adopted. 
Code amendments recommended by the respective code associations shall not be incorporated by reference as provided in the codes. The building official may adopt administrative regulations that incorporate by reference such subsequent changes and amendments thereof, properly identified as to date and source, as may be adopted by the agency or association that promulgated the code. Such amendment shall become effective upon the expiration of 90 calendar days following the publication of the regulations. 
(Code 1997, § 4-2-105; Ord. No. 2006-37, 8-27-2006)  
Sec. 8-51. - Prosecution for violations. 
The city manager may direct the city attorney or other legal counsel to prosecute all persons failing to comply with the terms of the notices and orders as provided for in various building and property maintenance codes adopted by the city. The city manager may direct that the attorney appear at hearings to assist the code official. At the direction of the city manager, the attorney shall bring suit to collect all municipal liens, assessments, or costs incurred by the city in repairing or causing to be vacated or demolished a structure in accordance with this article as directed by the city manager. At the direction of the city manager, the attorney shall take such other legal action as is necessary to carry out the terms and provisions of the building and property maintenance codes. 
(Code 1997, § 4-2-106; Ord. No. 2006-37, 8-27-2006)  
Sec. 8-52. - Procedure and notification. 
(a)  The following procedure shall be used for notifications of violations, notices, and orders of the building official or code official: 
(1)  Grass, weeds, trash, brush. It shall be unlawful for any person to fail to comply with an order by the code official to cut weeds and grass within five days when it has reached a height of over ten inches. 
a.  Notice to owner or person responsible. Whenever the code official determines that there has been a violation or has grounds to believe a violation has occurred, notice shall be given to the owner or the person responsible therefor in the manner prescribed herein. 
b.  Failure to comply. If the property owner of record fails or refuses to mow the grass or weeds as directed within ten days after receiving the notice, the code officer shall immediately cause the condition to be remedied and the cost thereof shall be assessed against the owner of the property. An administrative charge will be added to cover administrative expenses. Upon the filing of the notice with the office of the register of deeds in the county, the costs shall be a lien on the property in favor of the city, second only to liens of the state, county, and municipality for taxes, any lien of the city for special assessments, and any valid lien, right, or interest in such property duly recorded or duly perfected by filing, prior to the filing of such cleanup lien. These costs shall also be placed on the tax rolls of the municipality as a lien and shall be added to property tax bills to be collected at the same time and in the same manner as property taxes are collected. If the owner fails to pay the costs, they may be collected at the same time and in the same manner as delinquent property taxes are collected and shall be subject to the same penalty and interest as delinquent property taxes. 
c.  Form of notice. Such notice shall be in accordance with all of the following: 
1.  In writing. 
2.  Include a description of the real estate sufficient for identification. 
3.  Include a statement of the violation and why the notice is being issued. 
4.  Include a correction order allowing ten days time to cut or mow the property to municipal standards. 
5.  Inform the property owner of the right to appeal. 
(2)  Junked vehicles on private property. It shall be unlawful for any person to fail to comply with an order by the code official to remove junked and disabled vehicles within 20 days from the date the notice is received. 
a.  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this subsection (a)(2), shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection (a)(2)a, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Junk vehicle means a vehicle of any age that is damaged or defective in one or any combination of the following ways that either makes the vehicle immediately inoperable, or would prohibit the vehicle from being operated in a reasonably safe manner upon the public streets and highways under its own power if self-propelled, or while being towed or pushed, if not self-propelled: 
1.  Flat tires, missing tires, missing wheels or missing or partially or totally disassembled tires and wheels. 
2.  Missing or partially or totally disassembled essential parts of the vehicle's drive train, including, but not limited to, engine, transmission, transaxle, drive shaft, differential, or axle. 
3.  Extensive exterior body damage or missing or partially or totally disassembled essential body parts, including, but not limited to, fenders, doors, engine hood, bumpers, windshield, or windows. 
4.  Missing or partially or totally disassembled essential interior parts, including, but not limited to, driver's seat, steering wheel, instrument panel, clutch, brake, or gear shift lever. 
5.  Missing or partially or totally disassembled parts essential to the starting or running of the vehicle under its own power, including, but not limited to, the starter, generator or alternator, battery, distributor, gas tank, carburetor or fuel injection system, spark plugs, or radiator. 
6.  The interior is a container for metal, glass, paper, rags or other cloth, wood, auto parts, machinery, waste or discarded materials in such quantity, quality and arrangement that a driver cannot be properly seated in the vehicle. 
7.  Lying on the ground upside down, on its side, or at other extreme angle, sitting on block or suspended in the air by any other method. 
8.  General environment in which the vehicle sits, including, but not limited to the vegetation that has grown up around, in or through the vehicle, the collection of pools of water in the vehicle, and the accumulation of other garbage or debris around the vehicle. 
Vehicle means any machine propelled by power other than human power, designed to travel along the ground by the use of wheels, treads, self-laying tracks, runners, slides or skids, including, but not limited to, automobiles, trucks, motorcycles, motor scooters, go-carts, campers, tractors, trailers, tractor-trailers, buggies, wagons, and earth-moving equipment, and any part of the same. 
b.  Notice to owner or person responsible. Whenever the code official determines that there has been or has grounds to believe a violation has occurred, notice shall be given to the owner or person responsible therefor in the manner prescribed herein. 
c.  Failure to comply. If the property owner of record or person responsible fails or refuses to remove the junked or disabled vehicles within the time stated in the notice, the code officer shall issue a citation for the accused violator to appear in city court to answer the charges. 
d.  Form of notice. Such notice shall be in accordance with all of the following: 
1.  In writing. 
2.  Include a description of the real estate sufficient for identification. 
3.  Include a statement of the violation and why the notice is being issued. 
4.  Include a correction order allowing 20 days time to remove the junked or disabled vehicle. 
5.  Inform the property owner of the right to appeal. 
(3)  Building maintenance and structures. Whenever a petition is filed with the code official, by a public authority or by at least five residents of the city charging that any structure is unfit for human occupancy or use, or whenever it appears to the code officer that a structure is unfit for human occupation or use, the code officer shall, if his preliminary investigation discloses a basis for such charges, issue and cause to be served upon the owner of, and parties in interest of, such structure a complaint stating the charges in that respect and containing a notice that a hearing will be held before the code officer at a place therein fixed, not less than ten days nor more than 30 days after the service of the complaint; and the owner and parties in interest shall have the right to file an answer to the complaint and to appear in person, or otherwise, and give testimony at the time and place fixed in the complaint. If, after such notice and hearing, the public officer determines that the structure under consideration is unfit for human occupancy or use, he shall state in writing his finding of fact in support of such determination and shall issue and cause to be served upon the owner thereof an order: 
a.  If the repair, alteration or improvement of the structure can be made at a reasonable cost in relation to the value of the structure, not exceeding 50 percent of the reasonable value, requiring the owner, during the time specified in the order, to repair, alter, or improve such structure to render it fit for human occupancy or use or, to vacate and close the structure for human occupancy or use; or 
b.  If the repair, alteration or improvement of said structure cannot be made at a reasonable cost in relation to the value of the structure, not to exceed 50 percent of the value of the premises, requiring the owner within the time specified in the order, to remove or demolish such structure. 
(b)  When the estimated cost of repair exceeds 50 percent in the judgment of the code officer, and the owner insists on making repairs and improvements instead of demolition, he shall submit plans and specifications by a licensed architect or engineer for review and approval of the building official. The building official may issue a permit and allow the repairs in compliance with city standards. If the owner fails to repair, alter, improve or to vacate and close the structure, the code official may cause such structure to be vacated and closed; and the code official shall cause to be posted on the main entrance of any dwelling so closed, a placard with the following words: "This building is unfit for human occupancy or use; the use or occupation of this building for human occupancy or use is prohibited and unlawful." The public officer may issue a citation for the owner to appear before the city court to answer the complaint. If the owner fails to comply with an order, as specified above, to remove or demolish the structure, the code official may cause such structure to be removed and demolished. The code official shall immediately file a lien for the recovery of costs or the city attorney may be directed by the city manager to initiate legal proceedings for the recovery of cost. 
(Code 1997, § 4-2-108; Ord. No. 2006-37, 8-27-2006; Ord. No. 2009-20, 4-13-2009)  
Sec. 8-53. - Lien for expenses. 
The amount of the cost of such repairs, alterations or improvements, or vacating and closing, or removal or demolition of structures by the code official shall, upon the filing of the notice with the office of the register of deeds of the county, be a lien on the property in favor of the municipality, second only to liens of the state, county and municipality for taxes, any lien of the municipality for special assessments, and any valid lien, right, or interest in such property duly recorded or duly perfected by filing, prior to the filing of such notice. These costs shall be placed upon the tax rolls of the city as a lien and shall be added to property tax bills to be collected at the same time and in the same manner as property taxes are collected. If the owner fails to pay the costs, they may be collected at the same time and in the same manner as delinquent property taxes are collected and shall be subject to the same penalty and interest as delinquent property taxes. Nothing in this section shall be construed to impair or limit in any way the power of the city to define and declare nuisances and to cause their removal or abatement, by summary proceedings or otherwise. 
(Code 1997, § 4-2-109; Ord. No. 2006-37, 8-27-2006)  
Sec. 8-54. - Method of service. 
(a)  Notices shall be deemed to be properly served if a copy thereof is: 
(1)  Delivered personally; 
(2)  Sent by certified or first-class mail addressed to the last known address; or 
(3)  If the notice is returned showing that the letter was not delivered, a copy thereof shall be posted in a conspicuous place in or about the structure affected by such notice. 
(b)  Whenever the code official has condemned a structure or equipment under the provisions of the codes, notice shall, in addition to the procedure outlined in subsection (a) of this section, also be posted in a conspicuous place in or about the structure affected by such notice and served on the owner or the person responsible for the structure or equipment. 
(c)  If the whereabouts of such person is unknown and the same cannot be ascertained by the public officer in the exercise of reasonable diligence, the code official shall sign an affidavit to that effect. Then the serving of such complaint or order upon such person may be made by publishing the same once each week for two consecutive weeks in a newspaper printed and published in the city. In addition, a copy of such complaint or order shall be posted in a conspicuous place on the premises affected by the complaint or order. A copy of such complaint or order shall also be filed for record in the register's office of the county, and such shall have the same force and effect as other lis pendens notices provided by law. 
(Code 1997, § 4-2-110; Ord. No. 2006-37, 8-27-2006)  
Sec. 8-55. - Clean up or abatement at property owner's expense. 
If the property owner of record fails or refuses to remedy the condition within ten days after receiving the notice, or 20 days if the owner is a carrier engaged in the transportation of property or is a utility transmitting communications, electricity, gas, liquids, steam, sewage, or other materials, the code official shall immediately cause the condition to be remedied or removed at a cost in conformity with reasonable standards, and the cost thereof shall be assessed against the owner of the property. An administrative charge may be added to cover administrative expenses. 
(Code 1997, § 4-2-111; Ord. No. 2006-37, 8-27-2006)  
Sec. 8-56. - Abatement cost recovery. 
Whenever abatement is performed at the expense of the city, a statement shall be mailed to the registered owners outlining the cost of remediation and such cost shall be due and payable within 30 days. The city may, at its discretion, cause a lien to be placed upon the property at the same time of billing. A copy of the statement shall be provided to the city recorder and such shall be recorded as an account receivable on the books of the city. All payments shall be directed to the city recorder for proper entry. The city manager may direct the city attorney to take legal action to recover costs. 
(Code 1997, § 4-2-112; Ord. No. 2006-37, 8-27-2006)  
Sec. 8-57. - Lien for expenses. 
The amount of the cost of repairs, alterations or improvements, or vacating and closing, or removal or demolition of structures by the code official shall, upon the filing of the notice with the office of the register of deeds of the county, be a lien on the property in favor of the municipality, second only to liens of the state, county and municipality for taxes, any lien of the municipality for special assessments, and any valid lien, right, or interest in such property duly recorded or duly perfected by filing, prior to the filing of such notice. These costs shall be placed upon the tax rolls of the city as a lien and shall be added to property tax bills to be collected at the same time and in the same manner as property taxes are collected. If the owner fails to pay the costs, they may be collected at the same time and in the same manner as delinquent property taxes are collected and shall be subject to the same penalty and interest as delinquent property taxes. If the structure is removed or demolished by the public officer and the materials in his judgment have any significant market value, he shall sell the materials of such structure and shall credit the proceeds of such sale against the cost of the removal or demolition, and any balance remaining shall be deposited in the chancery court of the county by the code official, shall be secured in such manner as may be directed by such court, and shall be disbursed by such court; provided, however, that nothing in this section shall be construed to impair or limit in any way the power of the city to define and declare nuisances and to cause their removal or abatement, by summary proceedings or otherwise. The city recorder shall maintain a record of liens that indicate the date and nature of the lien, the amount of the lien, and the date the lien is released. The code official shall assist the recorder in maintaining the record. The building official shall be responsible for notifying the recorder of all liens filed. It is critical that satisfied liens are promptly and properly released. 
(Code 1997, § 4-2-113; Ord. No. 2006-37, 8-27-2006)  
Sec. 8-58. - Transfer of ownership. 
It shall be unlawful for the owner of any dwelling unit or structure who has received a compliance order or upon whom a notice of violation has been served to sell, transfer, mortgage, lease or otherwise dispose of such dwelling unit or structure to another until the provisions of the compliance order or notice of violation have been complied with, or until such owner shall first furnish the grantee, transferee, mortgagee or lessee a true copy of any compliance order or notice of violation issued by the code official and shall furnish to the code official a signed and notarized statement from the grantee, transferee, mortgagee or lessee, acknowledging the receipt of such compliance order or notice of violation and fully accepting the responsibility without condition for making the corrections or repairs required by such compliance order or notice of violation. 
(Code 1997, § 4-2-114; Ord. No. 2006-37, 8-27-2006)  
Sec. 8-59. - Building permit fees; plan review and inspection fees. 
(a)  A graduated building permit schedule for all nonresidential buildings is adopted as follows: 
Building Size in Square Footage 
(in square feet) 	Permit Fee 
(per square foot) 
10,000 or less 	$0.30 
10,00130,000 	 0.20 
30,00150,000 	 0.15 
50,001100,000 	 0.10 
100,001200,000 	 0.06 
200,001400,000 	 0.04 
400,001 or greater 	 0.03 
 
(b)  A plan review and inspection fee for all nonresidential buildings is adopted as follows: 
Building Size 
(in square feet) 	Plan Inspection Fee 
(per square foot) 
100,000 or less 	$0.05 
100,001 or greater 	$0.05, maximum of $20,000.00 
 
(c)  The plan review and inspection fee shall be payable at the time that construction plans are submitted, but shall be exclusive of the building permit fee. 
(Ord. No. 2005-06, §§ 13, 4-11-2005)  
Secs. 8-608-76. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IV. - REGULATIONS 
 
Sec. 8-77. - Exterior walls of metal buildings. 
(a)  All metal buildings erected within any commercial district shall be built with brick, stone, stucco or wood design exterior walls. 
(b)  Metal exteriors will continue to be permitted within agricultural, residential and industrial zoned districts only. 
(c)  Specifically excluded from subsections (a) and (b) of this section are ATM machines, metal roofing materials, metal accent trim, mansards, and metal canopies. 
(Ord. No. 2002-11, §§ 13, 2-25-2002)  
Sec. 8-78. - Fire resistant materials for exterior walls and roofs of residential structures. 
(a)  Exterior walls facing the lot line and the roof, other than openings such as windows, doors, and vents, of all residential structures constructed within 20 feet of the property line upon which the structure is located in the city shall be composed of materials having a minimum one-hour fire resistant rating, as tested by UL, or other similarly recognized independent testing agency. All roofs shall conform to a class A, or better, if applicable, fire retardant roofing in accordance with UBC standard No. 32-7, section 32.701. 
(b)  This section shall apply to all new construction and modular homes and as well to renovation, remodeling or additions to existing structures, which includes replacement or addition of materials within 20 feet of the side lot line of the property on which such structure is located. 
(c)  All builders, contractors and other persons acting in such capacity, shall produce evidence of compliance with the requirements of this section satisfactory to the city manager or his designee as a condition of approval of said construction and issuance of permits for use and occupancy. 
(d)  All manufactured homes located in mobile home parks shall be exempt from this section. This section shall not apply to setbacks from lot lines directly adjacent to paved streets. 
(e)  Exterior walls facing the lot line, which are fully constructed of brick, will be exempt from this section. 
(Ord. No. 2003-11, §§ 15, 2-10-2003)  
Sec. 8-79. - Supplemental residential requirements for single-family and duplex dwellings. 
(a)  Exterior walls on vinyl sided dwellings. 
(1)  All vinyl siding shall have a minimum thickness specification of 0.042 inches. 
(2)  All vinyl siding installed as wall material less than or equal to 20 feet from a property line, shall comply with the requirements of Ordinance 2003-11 (section 8-78 above). Vinyl siding installed on walls greater than 20 feet from a property line shall have a solid backing of 7/16 inch OSB material or other suitable material approved by the Building Official. 
(3)  All vinyl materials used for siding and trim shall be certified as mold and mildew resistant. 
(4)  Installers of vinyl siding shall be certified by the Vinyl Siding Institute. 
(b)  Foundations. 
(1)  Unfinished foundation work or materials, such as CMU block, shall not be exposed. Vented and unvented foundations may utilize brick, hard coat stucco, or other treatments deemed acceptable by the City of Mt. Juliet, Regional Planning Commission below the finished floor elevation. 
(2)  If "conditioned" crawl spaces are installed they shall be constructed per the International Residential Code as adopted. 
(c)  Heating and cooling systems. No wall or window mounted air conditioning or heating units may be installed or placed in a front or street facing facade (excluding alleys). Such units may be located in a side or rear facade not adjacent to a street. 
(Ord. No. 2011-17, § 1, 4-11-2011)  
Secs. 8-808-99. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE V. - MANUFACTURED HOMES 
 
Sec. 8-100. - Permanent masonry foundations required. 
(a)  All new manufactured homes placed on any property located in the city hereinafter shall be placed on permanent masonry footings and foundations of concrete block, brick, rock or other similar materials approved by the public works department and in conformity with the requirements of the 1999 SBCCI code. 
(b)  Any manufactured home replacing existing manufactured homes on any property in the city hereinafter shall be placed on permanent masonry footing and foundation of concrete block, brick, rock or other similar materials approved by the public works department and in conformity with the requirements of the 1999 SBCCI code. 
(Ord. No. 2002-48, §§ 1, 2, 12-23-2002)  
Sec. 8-101. - Adequately skirted. 
All manufactured homes located in mobile home parks shall be adequately skirted, so as to minimize to the extent possible the impact of wind on any such structure. 
(Ord. No. 2002-48, § 3, 12-23-2002)  
Sec. 8-102. - Treated as mobile home when located in mobile home park. 
Manufactured homes located in mobile home parks shall be treated as mobile homes and shall be exempt from the mandatory requirements of this article, except as provided in section 8-101. 
(Ord. No. 2002-48, § 4, 12-23-2002)  
Chapter 10 - BUSINESSES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference Business licensing, T.C.A. § 67-4-708. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Secs. 10-110-18. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - SOLICITORS AND PEDDLERS  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 10-19. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Charitable means and includes the terms "patriotic," "philanthropic," "social service," "health," "welfare," "benevolent," "educational," "civic" "cultural" or "fraternal," either actual or purported. 
Chief means the chief of police. 
Contributions means and includes the terms "alms," "money," "subscription," "property" or any donations under the guise of a loan or money or property. 
Department means the police department. 
Peddler means any person who goes upon the premises of any private residence in the city, not having been invited by the occupant thereof, carrying or transporting goods, wares, merchandise or personal property of any nature and offering the same for sale. The term "peddler" includes any person who solicits orders and as a separate transaction makes deliveries to purchasers as part of the scheme to evade the provisions of this article. 
Peddling includes all activities ordinarily performed by a peddler as indicated in the definition of "peddler" in this section. 
Solicitation includes all activities ordinarily performed by a solicitor as indicated in the definition of the term "solicitor" in this section. 
Solicitor means any person who goes upon the premises of any private residence in the city, not having been invited by the occupant thereof, for the purpose taking or attempting to take orders for the sale of goods, merchandise, wares, or other personal property of any nature for future delivery, or for services to be performed in the future. The term "solicitor" includes any person who, without invitation, goes upon private property, to request contribution of funds or anything of value, or sells goods or services for political, charitable, religious, or other noncommercial purposes. 
(Code 1997, § 5-2-101)  
Sec. 10-20. - Violations and penalty. 
(a)  Violation of any of the provisions of this article shall be treated as an infraction, and shall, upon conviction, be punishable by a fine of up to $500.00. 
(b)  In addition to criminal enforcement, the city or any individual may pursue any available civil remedies deemed appropriate and necessary. 
(Code 1997, § 5-2-119)  
Sec. 10-21. - Bond. 
All solicitors requiring cash deposits or taking orders for cash on delivery purchases (COD) or who require a contract of agreement to finance the sale of any goods, services, or merchandise for future delivery, or for services to be performed in the future, shall furnish to the department a bond in the amount of $500.00. 
(Code 1997, § 5-2-106)  
Sec. 10-22. - Entry upon signed premises unlawful. 
It shall be unlawful for any person, whether licensed or unlicensed, while conducting the business of a peddler or solicitor, to enter upon any residential premises in the city where the owner, occupant or person legally in charge of the premises has posted, at the entry to the premises, or at the entry to the principal building on the premises, a sign bearing the words "No Peddlers," "No Solicitors," or words of similar import. 
(Code 1997, § 5-2-113)  
Sec. 10-23. - Hours of solicitation. 
No person, while conducting the activities of a peddler or solicitor, whether licensed or unlicensed, shall enter upon any private property, knock on doors or otherwise disturb persons in their residences between the hours of 9:00 p.m. and 9:00 a.m. 
(Code 1997, § 5-2-114)  
Secs. 10-2410-49. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - PERMIT 
 
Sec. 10-50. - Requirements and exemptions. 
It shall be unlawful for any person 18 years of age or older to engage in peddling or solicitation activities within the city without first obtaining a permit issued by the chief of police; provided, however, that the following are exempted from the provisions of this section: 
(1)  Any solicitation made upon premises owned or occupied by an organization upon whose behalf the solicitation is made; 
(2)  Any communication by an organization soliciting contributions solely from persons who are members of the organization at the time of such solicitation; 
(3)  Any solicitation in the form of a collection at a regular meeting, assembly or service of a charitable person; or 
(4)  Any solicitation for the relief of any individual specified by name at the time of the solicitation where the solicitor represents in each case that the entire amount collected shall be turned over to the named beneficiary. 
(Code 1997, § 5-2-102)  
Sec. 10-51. - Sponsoring juvenile peddlers. 
(a)  No person under the age of 18 shall be permitted to engage in peddling except on behalf of his school, church or a charitable organization. No permit or license shall be required for minors engaging in such permitted solicitation so long as they are supervised by an adult. 
(b)  A permit shall be obtained by a sponsoring person, company or organization for the conduct of any peddling or solicitation activities involving, in whole or in part, a sales force of one or more persons under 18 years of age. 
(c)  The sponsor shall be responsible for supervising and controlling the conduct of all persons, including juveniles, peddling under the sponsor's permit. 
(Code 1997, § 5-2-103)  
Sec. 10-52. - Application. 
Every person subject to the provisions of this article shall file with the city an application in writing on a form to be furnished by the city, which shall provide the following information: 
(1)  Proof of age, address and identification of the applicant, to be provided through the applicant's driver's license, articles of incorporation (for sponsors), or other legally recognized form of identification; 
(2)  A brief description of the business or activity to be conducted; 
(3)  The hours and location for which the right to peddle or solicit is desired; 
(4)  If employed, the name, address and telephone number of the employer; or if acting as an agent, the name, address and telephone number of the principal who is being represented, with credentials in written form establishing the relationship and the authority of the employee or agent to act for the employer or principal, as the case may be; 
(5)  A statement as to whether or not the applicant has been convicted of a felony, misdemeanor or ordinance violation other than traffic violations, the nature of the offense or violation, the penalty or punishment imposed, the date when and place where such offense occurred, and other pertinent details thereof; 
(6)  Proof of possession of any license or permit which, under federal, state or local laws or regulations, the applicant is required to have in order to conduct the proposed business, or which, under any such law or regulation, would exempt the applicant from the licensing requirements of this article; and 
(7)  A copy of the driver's license of the applicant. 
(Code 1997, § 5-2-104)  
Sec. 10-53. - Fees. 
At the time the application is filed with the department, the applicant shall pay a fee to cover the cost to the city of processing the application and investigating the facts stated therein. The permit fee shall be $50.00 for each solicitor or peddler for each 14-day period of solicitation. See T.C.A. §§ 67-4-709 and 67-4-719. 
(Code 1997, § 5-2-105)  
Sec. 10-54. - Review and permit issuance. 
(a)  Upon receipt of an application, the city shall review the application as deemed necessary to ensure the protection of the public health, safety and general welfare. 
(b)  If the city finds the application to be satisfactory, it shall, upon payment of the prescribed fee, deliver the required permit to the applicant. 
(c)  The permit shall show the name, address and photograph of the permittee, the class of permit issued, the kind of goods or services to be sold or delivered, the date of issuance, and the length of time that the permit shall be in effect. The permit shall also show the permit number and identifying description of any vehicle to be used in carrying on the business for which the permit is issued. 
(d)  A record of all permits issued shall be maintained by the city for a period of two years. 
(Code 1997, § 5-2-107)  
Sec. 10-55. - Denial. 
(a)  Upon the review of the application, the city may refuse to issue a permit to the applicant under this article for any of the following reasons: 
(1)  The location and time of solicitation or peddling would endanger the safety and welfare of the solicitors, peddlers or their customers; 
(2)  An investigation reveals that the applicant falsified information on the application; 
(3)  The applicant has been convicted of a felony, misdemeanor or ordinance violation involving a sex offense, trafficking in controlled substances, or any violent acts against persons or property, such conviction being entered within the five years preceding the date of application; 
(4)  The applicant is a person against whom a judgment based upon, or conviction for, fraud, deceit or misrepresentation has been entered within the five years immediately preceding the date of application; 
(5)  There is no proof as to the authority of the applicant to serve as an agent to the principal; or 
(6)  The applicant has been denied a permit under this article within the immediate past year, unless the applicant can and does show to the satisfaction of the city that the reasons for such earlier denial no longer exist. 
(b)  The city's disapproval and the reasons for disapproval shall be noted on the application, and the applicant shall be notified that his application is disapproved and that no permit will be issued. Notice shall be mailed to the applicant at the address shown on the application form, or at the applicant's last known address. 
(Code 1997, § 5-2-108)  
Sec. 10-56. - Expiration. 
All permits issued under the provisions of this article shall expire one year from the date of issuance, unless an earlier expiration date is noted on the permit. 
(Code 1997, § 5-2-109)  
Sec. 10-57. - Exhibited upon request. 
Every person required to obtain a permit under the provisions of this article shall exhibit the permit when requested to do so by any prospective customer or department employee. 
(Code 1997, § 5-2-111)  
Sec. 10-58. - Transferability. 
It shall be unlawful for any person other than the permittee to use any permit issued under the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1997, § 5-2-112)  
Sec. 10-59. - Revocation. 
Any permit issued under this article may be revoked or suspended by the chief of police, after notice and hearing, for any of the following reasons: 
(1)  Fraud, misrepresentation or false statement contained in the application for a permit; 
(2)  Fraud, misrepresentation or false statement made by the permittee in the course of conducting solicitation or peddling activities; 
(3)  Conducting peddling or solicitation activities contrary to the provisions contained in the permit; 
(4)  Conviction for any crime involving moral turpitude; or 
(5)  Conducting peddling or solicitation activities in such a manner as to create a public nuisance, constitute a breach of the peace or endanger the health, safety or general welfare of the public. 
(Code 1997, § 5-2-115)  
Sec. 10-60. - Notice and hearing. 
Notice of a hearing for revocation of a permit issued under this article shall be provided in writing and shall set forth specifically the grounds for the proposed revocation and the time and place of the hearing. Notice shall be mailed, postage prepaid, to the permittee at the address shown on the permit application or at the last known address of the permittee. 
(Code 1997, § 5-2-116)  
Sec. 10-61. - Appeals. 
(a)  Any person aggrieved by the action or decision of the chief of police to deny, suspend or revoke a permit applied for under the provisions of this article shall have the right to appeal such action or decision to the city manager within 15 days after the notice of the action or decision has been mailed to the person's address as shown on the permit application form, or to his last known address. 
(b)  An appeal shall be taken by filing with the chief a written statement setting forth the grounds for the appeal. 
(c)  The chief shall transmit the written statement to the city manager within ten days of its receipt and the city manager shall set a time and place for a hearing on the appeal. 
(d)  A hearing shall be set not later than 20 days from the date of receipt of the appellant's written statement. 
(e)  Notice of the time and place of the hearing shall be given to the appellant in the same manner as provided for the mailing of notice of action or decision. 
(f)  The decision of the city manager on the appeal shall be final and binding on all parties concerned. 
(Code 1997, § 5-2-117)  
Sec. 10-62. - Claims of exemption. 
Any person claiming to be legally exempt from the regulations set forth in this article, or from the payment of a permit fee, shall cite to the chief of police the statute or other legal authority under which exemption is claimed and shall present to the chief proof of qualification for such exemption. 
(Code 1997, § 5-2-118)  
Secs. 10-6310-82. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - AGGRESSIVE SOLICITATION[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note Provisions pertaining to aggressive solicitation appear in article V of chapter 16 of this Code. 
 
Secs. 10-8310-115. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IV. - SECONDHAND JEWELRY, ETC. 
 
Sec. 10-116. - Records required. 
It shall be the duty of all persons dealing in the purchase, sale, or exchange of secondhand or antique jewelry, gold coins, watches, diamonds or other precious stones, cutlery, old gold, silver, platinum, or other precious metals, or any other secondhand manufactured articles, composed wholly or in part of gold, silver, platinum, or other precious metals, to keep a book in which every article received by them in the course of their business shall be registered, and in which shall be given as minute a description of every article as possible, including the maker's name and number of every article so received by them. The name, age, sex color, residence, driver's license number, and general description of every individual selling or exchanging such articles shall be taken and entered in the register. The register shall at all times be kept at the place of business of every person engaging in the business. Members of the city police department shall be allowed free access to the register and the person shall give to such officers all information in his possession concerning such articles and all persons selling or exchanging the same. 
(Code 1997, § 5-4-101; Ord. No. 81-3, § 1, 1-19-1981)  
Sec. 10-117. - Retention of articles. 
All persons engaging in the business as described herein shall retain any article received in the same state or condition in which it was received, and shall not commingle it with other articles separately received, and shall make it available for examination by members of the police department, for a period of 15 days before a resale or exchange, unless written permission is obtained from the chief of police to dispose of the articles. 
(Code 1997, § 5-4-102; Ord. No. 81-3, § 1, 1-19-1981)  
Sec. 10-118. - Daily reports; transient businesses. 
All persons engaging in business as described herein shall furnish to the chief of police daily reports at his office, showing fully the name, age, sex, color, residence, driver's license number, and general description of each person who shall have sold or exchanged any article during the preceding day, together with a full description of the articles sold or exchanged by such person, including the number of each article bearing a number, and the day and hour of the transaction. Every person engaging in such business shall keep duplicates of such reports in a well-bound book or register, which book or register shall at all times be subject to the inspection of the members of the police department. Any person intending to engage in the business as described herein who will not operate that business at an established and permanent location shall give the chief of police at least 72 hours' prior notice of the location and date and hours of the operation of such business. 
(Code 1997, § 5-4-103; Ord. No. 81-3, § 3, 1-19-1981)  
Secs. 10-11910-149. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE V. - CABLE TELEVISION 
 
Sec. 10-150. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Basic cable service means any service tier that includes the retransmission of local television broadcast signals, or as may be further defined by the rules and regulations of the Federal Communications Commission. 
Cable act means the Cable Communications Policy Act of 1984, 47 USC 541 et seq., as amended by the Cable Television Consumer Protection and Competition Act of 1992, and as may be further amended or replaced. 
Cable system means the collection of fiber optic strands, coaxial cables, copper wire or other physical links placed on the public rights-of-way to carry electromagnetic or optical signals and the devices connected to them. 
Cable television service means operation of a cable system distributing video signals and communication services related to the video signals to the general public. 
Cable television system means a facility utilized to distribute video signals over a cable system for sale to the general public and all related facilities utilized to provide communication services related to the video signals. Excluded from the definition are components of the cable system utilized to provide communication services not related to the video signals sold to the general public. 
Channel means a portion of the electromagnetic or optical frequency spectrum used to carry one broadcast signal. 
City commission means the commission of the City of Mt. Juliet, State of Tennessee. 
FCC means the Federal Communications Commission. 
Franchise means the nonexclusive rights granted pursuant to this article and a franchise agreement to utilize the public rights-of-way to place, utilize and maintain a cable system within the city. A franchise shall not include any general license or permit required for the privilege of transacting and carrying on a business within the city as required by other ordinances and laws. 
Franchise agreement means a contract entered into between the city and a grantee authorizing the grantee to utilize the public right-of-way. 
Grantee means a legal entity to whom the city commission grants a franchise under this article and the lawful successor, transferee or assignee of the grantee. 
Gross revenues means all revenue received by the grantee and its subsidiaries or parents, from the operation of the cable system in the city. The term "gross revenues" includes both television revenues and nontelevision revenues. The term "gross revenues" includes all sources of income or earnings that directly depend on the cable system. The term "gross revenues" includes all income received by related business for utilization of the cable system or for signals transmitted over the cable system. The term "gross receipts" includes charges for use of the cable system to transmit data for a fee. 
Nontelevision revenues means all revenues received by the grantee and its subsidiaries or parents, from the operation of the cable system in the city for other communication services to the extent not prohibited by state or federal law. 
Other communication services means any use of the cable system for purposes not related to cable television service. 
Public way means streets, easements, paths and rights-of-way of any kind over which the city has the right of passage with a cable. 
Residential subscriber means a subscriber who receives cable television service in a single-family home or in an individual dwelling unit of a multiple dwelling. 
Service area means the geographical area within the city and within which the grantee is authorized to construct, operate and maintain a cable television system. 
Street means the surface of and the space above and below any publicly owned or maintained property or right-of-way, street, road, highway, freeway, land, path, alley, court, sidewalk, parkway, or drive, now or hereafter existing within the city. 
Subscriber means any person or entity lawfully receiving any portion of the cable television service of a grantee pursuant to this article. 
Television revenues means all income from the sale of video signals to the general public including basic service, premium channels, pay-per-view, advertising sales, receipts for use of commercial and home shopping channels, installation and reconnection fees, and converter and other equipment rentals and income from the sale of television time, television products or television services are included. 
(Code 1997, § 5-5-102)  
Sec. 10-151. - CATV committee. 
(a)  The city commission hereby establishes a CATV committee composed of five members appointed by the mayor and approved by the commissioners. 
(b)  Each member of the CATV committee shall serve a term of five years. Members shall be appointed for initial terms to stagger the expiration of their terms so that one term expires annually. 
(c)  The CATV committee shall regulate access to PEG channels and advise the city commission concerning cable TV and telecommunications. 
(d)  All meetings of the CATV committee shall be open to the public. Meetings shall be televised on a PEG channel when possible. If a meeting is televised then no advance public notice shall be required, but advance public notice is suggested when possible. 
(Code 1997, § 5-5-103)  
Sec. 10-152. - Franchise. 
(a)  Required. No person shall construct, operate or maintain a cable television system in the city without a franchise agreement issued by the city. 
(b)  Service area. The service area for each franchise shall be the entire city or such lesser portion of the city as is designated in the franchise agreement. 
(c)  Telephones. Cable companies are urged to provide telephone service over the cable television system as soon as it is both legal and practical. Grantees shall make no anticompetitive arrangements with telephone companies. Grantees shall allow other utilities to use its poles under the same conditions which those utilities impose on the grantee. 
(d)  Franchise agreement. 
(1)  Required. No entity, except the city, may utilize public rights-of-way to construct, operate or maintain a cable system without a franchise agreement from the city or a certificate of authority from the state public service commission. All franchises shall contain substantially similar terms. 
(2)  Effective date. No franchise agreement shall become effective until approved by the city commission by ordinance and executed by the mayor and by the grantee. Within 30 working days after final passage of the ordinance authorizing execution of the franchise agreement the grantee shall execute the franchise agreement and file with the city recorder an insurance certificate. Each franchisee shall agree to comply with the provisions of this article and other applicable law. 
(3)  Franchise term. The duration of a new franchise agreement shall not exceed 15 years. The duration of a renewed franchise shall not exceed ten years. 
(4)  Franchise revocation. 
a.  Grounds for revocation. Subject to the provisions of this section, the city reserves the right to revoke, at any time, any franchise and rescind all rights and privileges if the grantee: 
1.  Has not substantially complied with a material provision of this article, the franchise agreement, or of any supplemental written agreement entered into by and between the city and the grantee; 
2.  Has made a material false statement in the application for the franchise, knowing it to be false, or the grantee commits a fraud in its conduct or relations under the franchise with the city; 
3.  Becomes insolvent, enters into receivership or liquidation, files for bankruptcy or assignment for benefit of creditors, or is unable to pay its debts as they mature, unless the grantee is in due process of contesting such debts; 
4.  Knowingly fails to substantially comply with a material provision of any state or federal law or regulation; 
5.  Exhibits a pattern of failing to substantially comply with service standards of the FCC; 
6.  Fails to comply with any final federal or state judgment arising directly from the exercise of the grantee's rights under its franchise; or 
7.  Assigns, sells or transfers its title or interest in its franchise without the consent of the city commission. 
b.  Revocation procedure. If the city makes a preliminary decision to revoke a franchise, it shall give the grantee a minimum of 60 days' written notice of its intention to terminate and state the cause. The city shall schedule a public hearing at the end of the period. If during the period, the grantee cures the default the city shall declare the notice null and void. Before the city terminates a franchise it must provide the grantee an opportunity to be heard. The city commission shall hear the proof of the grantee in a public hearing concerning why the city should not revoke the charter. This meeting shall be televised. After the public hearing, if the city commission, by majority vote, determines that the franchise should be terminated, it shall issue a written decision containing its findings of fact and stating the specific grounds for termination. The decision to terminate a franchise shall be subject to judicial review. 
c.  Limitations on revocation. A grantee shall not be declared in default or be subject to any sanction under any provision of this article in any case where the city commission determines that the action justifying such sanction is without the grantee's knowledge or authorization or outside its control. 
(5)  Franchise authority. A grantee is authorized to construct, operate, and maintain a cable system, and to engage in the business of providing cable service in the city. The grantee may erect, install, construct, repair, replace, reconstruct and maintain such poles, wires, cables, conductors, ducts, conduits, vaults, manholes, amplifiers, appliances, attachments, and other property as may be necessary and appurtenant to the cable system. Before cutting any street or erecting any pole within 15 feet of the pavement the grantee shall furnish plans and obtain permission from the public works director of the city. 
(6)  Fees. 
a.  Application. Each applicant for a new franchise shall pay an application fee to the city of $2,500.00 which sum shall become due and payable to the city upon submission to the city of an application for a franchise or as soon thereafter as demanded by the city manager of the city. The application fee shall be nonrefundable. 
b.  Annual franchise. For use of public rights-of-way and administration of the franchise each grantee shall pay franchise fees as follows: 
1.  For television revenues. The maximum franchise fee allowed by state and federal law which at the current time is five percent of gross revenue. 
2.  For nontelevision revenues. From all nontelevision revenue the grantee shall pay a franchise fee equal to the same percentage rate as the franchise fee on television revenues unless the following conditions exist: 
(i)  The income stream is derived from an endeavor in which the grantee is in direct competition with another company providing similar services and the competing company does not pay a similar franchise fee; or 
(ii)  The rates of the grantee on the nontelevision revenue are set by the state public service commission. 
Upon request the grantee shall disclose all nontelevision revenue and explain why no franchise fee is due. 
3.  Time of payment. Each grantee shall pay the franchise fee quarterly not later than 60 days after the last day of each calendar quarter. 
4.  Franchise fees. The fee shall be in addition to any and all taxes which are now or may be required hereafter to be paid pursuant to any federal, state, or local law. The franchise fee shall not be in lieu of any other general tax, fee or assessment. Any federal, state or local taxes, fees or imposed charges collected by the grantee shall not be considered part of the revenue upon which franchise fees are based. 
c.  Financial reports. Grantees shall annually furnish to the city recorder a financial statement showing the gross receipts of the cable system. The statement shall break the gross into categories for each tier of channels, advertising, equipment rental, bandwidth or cable rental and such other categories as may be required to assess the accuracy of the statement. The grantee shall furnish the statement not later than four months after the end of its fiscal year. The statement shall be signed under oath by the chief executive officer, the chief financial officer and the manager of the system. The oath shall state: 
"The undersigned individuals certify that this statement accurately reflects the gross earnings of the franchise located in Mt. Juliet. The gross earnings includes all money received by any parent or subsidiary for use of the cable system in any manner, including advertising sales and fees for cable rental or data transmission. No source of revenue for any related entity has been excluded. We realize that we have been duly sworn and make this representation under penalties of perjury. We realize that perjury is a Class A misdemeanor and that aggravated perjury is a Class D felony." 
The city may require that the financial statement be audited. 
d.  Audit. The grantee shall authorize the city to inspect the grantee's contracts and records dealing with gross revenue and to have the books and records audited. If any audit discloses an error of more than five percent the franchisee shall pay the expense of the audit and shall not pass the expense through to city customers. If the audit discloses no error or an error of less than five percent the city shall pay the cost of the audit. 
(7)  Liability and indemnification. All franchise agreements shall require the grantee to indemnify, defend and save harmless the city, its officers, committees, commissions, and employees against any and all actions, liability, judgments, claims or demands arising out of the installation or operation or maintenance of the cable television system, including all costs of defense. 
(Code 1997, § 5-5-104)  
Sec. 10-153. - Transfer of system. 
(a)  Approval required. No transfer of control of the cable television system shall occur without prior approval by the city commission, which approval shall not be unreasonably withheld. 
(b)  Conditions. No transfer may occur without full compliance with the material terms of the franchise and this article. The transferee shall agree in writing to comply with all provisions of this article and the franchise agreement. 
(c)  Commission approval. If the city commission does not disapprove a proposed transfer of control within 90 days from the date the notice is received by the city recorder the parties to the transfer shall assume the transfer is approved. 
(d)  Control. The term "control" is not limited to majority stock ownership, but includes actual working control in whatever manner exercised. A rebuttal presumption that a transfer of control has occurred shall arise upon the acquisition or accumulation by any person or group of affiliated persons of 25 percent of the voting shares of the grantee. 
(e)  Mortgage of system. The grantee shall not be required to notify the city of a mortgage or hypothecation of the cable system to secure a commercial loan to an independent licensed financial institution, but any documents granting a security interest in the cable system shall include as exhibits this article and the franchise agreement. 
(f)  Foreclosure. No secured creditor shall foreclose or sell any part of the cable system without prior notice to the city. If the grantee or any secured creditor desires to sell the franchise assets they shall notify the city of the price of any proposed transfer. The city may purchase the assets for the same price and on the same terms at any time within 30 days of the notice and neither the grantee nor the representative of a creditor may transfer the franchise or its assets to others for less than the notice price. 
(Code 1997, § 5-5-105)  
Sec. 10-154. - Streets and easements. 
(a)  Relocation of wires. Upon notice by the city, the grantee shall, at its expense, temporarily remove or relocate its cables and equipment from limited areas of public ways to facilitate public works or inconsistent use of the area by others. In emergencies or to speed public works the city may move wires at the expense of the grantee. If wires over a street are 16 feet or more in height and are removed or relocated at the request of another citizen, that person shall pay the cost. 
(b)  Underground conduits. Prior to building underground conduits the grantee shall furnish to the city plans and projected costs. The city may require the grantee to increase the size or number of conduits, at the city's expense, to carry other utilities or cables. The portion of such conduits financed with city funds shall belong to the city. 
(c)  Repair of streets. If the grantee disturbs any street or other property it shall repair the damage to the satisfaction of the public works director. The grantee shall contract, maintain and operate the cable television system so as to cause minimum inconvenience to the general public. All excavations shall be properly guarded, marked and protected. All excavations shall be filled and the surface restored promptly after completion of the work. The grantee shall at all times comply with all excavation ordinances of the city. 
(d)  Use of the public ways. 
(1)  The city may install and maintain free of charge upon the poles or in the conduits of a grantee any wire and pole fixtures necessary for municipal networks such as police, fire, public works and utilities, on the condition that such installations and maintenance shall not interfere with the operations of the grantee. 
(2)  The grantee shall minimize its use of the public ways to accomplish its tasks with the minimum impact on others who desire to use the public ways. 
(3)  The grantee shall place its wires on poles in such a manner as to maximize the use of the same poles by others. 
(4)  All grantees shall to the maximum extent possible share poles, conduits and other devices on the public ways to minimize the number of structures on the public ways. 
(5)  The grantee shall remove all of its structures, wires and devices from the public ways within 12 months of the termination or abandonment of its franchise unless the city at that time permits it to abandon the devices in place. The city may charge a grantee for the cost of removal of wires and devices from the public ways. 
(e)  Underground wiring. Trunk and distribution lines, including service drops to subscribers, shall be made underground in areas where both telephone and power lines are underground. 
(Code 1997, § 5-5-106)  
Sec. 10-155. - Public, educational and governmental (PEG) usage. 
(a)  Service to government buildings. The grantee shall provide without charge one service outlet to all public education institutions and governmental buildings within the service area. The institution shall receive the grantee's basic cable service, all news channels and all public, educational and governmental channels. The recipient shall bear the cost of all internal wiring. The grantee shall install and maintain at city hall, Mt. Juliet High School, and the proposed community center a two-way feed to provide the capability of receiving and originating programming to the PEG channels. The grantee shall provide and maintain the modulators, processors, recorders and equipment to accomplish the insertion and retransmission of programming on the PEG channels. 
(b)  Emergency broadcast system. The grantee shall provide, without charge and subject to the rules and regulations of the FCC, public emergency broadcast capabilities whereby the city can interrupt service and/or insert announcements on all channels in order to make such public emergency communications as it deems necessary. 
(c)  PEG channels. When the cable system has a 52-channel capacity, the grantee shall reserve a minimum of two channels for public, educational governmental access use. Systems with a smaller capacity shall provide one such channel. Such channels shall be subject to the exclusive control of the city; however, with prior approval of the city, such channels may be used by the grantee for other purposes when not required by PEG users. The grantee shall make available to users, subject to advance scheduling and during the grantee's normal business hours, its equipment at no charge. The city or its designee shall regulate and schedule the use of PEG channels. PEG channels shall not be used to advertise the sale of services or products or events for commercial or for-profit entities. PEG channels may be used to advertise events held by nonprofit entities and for sale of services or products by governmental or charitable organizations. 
(Code 1997, § 5-5-107)  
Sec. 10-156. - Quality standards. 
(a)  Construction. 
(1)  The grantee shall maintain the cable system in a manner consistent with all laws, construction standards and governmental requirements including those set out in 47 CFR 76.601 et seq., the FCC standards. 
(2)  Grantees shall install hardware so as to cause minimum interference with other users of streets, utility poles and public property. Underground street crossings shall normally be done by tunneling or boring. Ditches and other street cuts shall be restored to a condition satisfactory to the public works director. 
(3)  Grantees shall have an electric generator at the head end to avoid power outages which cause an interruption in service. The grantee shall test the system monthly. 
(4)  Grantees shall furnish to the city public works director maps and plans of its entire system. The plans and maps shall be of the best quality of the maps and plans in the possession of the grantee. 
(b)  Operation. 
(1)  Complaint and maintenance log. Subject to the privacy provisions of section 631 of the Cable Act, the grantee shall keep a maintenance service log indicating the nature of each service complaint, the date and time it was received, the disposition of the complaint and the date and time of the disposition. The log shall be made available for periodic inspection by the city manger or his designee. The grantee shall provide monthly maintenance summaries to the city manager on demand. 
(2)  Inspection. The city may inspect the grantee's system to ensure compliance with the terms of the ordinance. At the city's own expense, the city or its designees may perform measurements upon and randomly inspect any portion of a grantee's system to ensure compliance with minimum technical standards under which the grantee is required to operate. If the tests disclose a violation of the required technical standards the grantee shall pay the cost of the tests and shall eliminate the defects. 
(3)  Filings with regulatory agencies. The grantee shall furnish copies of all petitions, applications and forms, relative to the franchise transmitted by the grantee to the FCC. 
(c)  Emergencies. The grantee shall assist the city manager or chief of police to use the grantee's system, at no cost, to broadcast emergency messages. 
(d)  Channels. Within three years after the effective date of a franchise agreement or renewal, the cable television system shall have a capacity which permits at least 54 channels. Within 12 months all customers shall receive similar service to all other customers within the system. 
(e)  Right to maintain antenna. The grantee shall not condition service to a subscriber by removing or disconnecting an antenna. The grantee may not disconnect an antenna without permission of the owner. 
(Code 1997, § 5-5-108)  
Sec. 10-157. - Rates and charges. 
The grantee shall file with the city schedules which shall describe all services offered, all rates and charges of any kind, and all terms and conditions relating thereto. The city commission reserves the right and authority to regulate the grantee's rates and charges to the extent allowed by law. 
(Code 1997, § 5-5-109)  
Sec. 10-158. - Amendments. 
This article may be amended from time to time. The provisions of any amendment shall be deemed to be a part of any franchise agreement from and after the legal date of the amendment. The city shall give all franchisees advance notice of any amendment and an opportunity to be heard. The city shall hold a public hearing prior to the final reading of any amendment. 
(Code 1997, § 5-5-110)  
Secs. 10-15910-184. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VI. - FIREWORKS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note Ord. No. 2012-01, § 1, adopted Jan. 23, 2012, repealed the former Art. VI, §§ 10-18510-194, and enacted a new Art. VI as set out herein. The former Art. VI pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Code 1997, §§ 5-6-1015-6-110; Ord. No. 2002-17, adopted June 10, 2002; Ord. No. 2002-26, §§ 5-6-1015-6-110, adopted Aug. 26, 2002. 
 
Sec. 10-185. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Approved means acceptable to the code official or authority having jurisdiction. 
DOT Class C common fireworks means all articles of fireworks as are now or hereafter classified as DOT Class C common fireworks in the regulations of the United States Department of Transportation. 
Permit means the written authority of the city codes director issued under the authority of this article. 
Retailer means any person engaged in the business of making retail sales of fireworks. 
Sale means an exchange of articles of fireworks for money and also includes barter, exchange, gift, or offer thereof and each such transaction made by any person, whether as principal, proprietor, salesperson, agent, association, co partnership, or one or more individuals. 
State fire marshal permit means the appropriate fireworks permit issued by the state fire marshal under the authority of T.C.A. § 68-104-101 et seq. 
(Ord. No. 2012-01, § 1, 1-23-2012)  
Sec. 10-186. - Penalty for violations. 
All individuals that violate any provision of this article shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction shall be punished by a fine not to exceed $50.00 plus costs. Each rule violation or transaction shall be considered a separate violation. Employers of fireworks vendors and permit holders shall also be guilty for violations by persons in their employment and persons under their supervision. 
(Ord. No. 2012-01, § 1, 1-23-2012)  
Sec. 10-187. - Permits; fees. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to sell, offer for sale, ship, or cause to be shipped, into the city any item of fireworks without first having secured a state fire marshal permit, and a permit issued by the city, which permit shall not issue without the applicants first providing satisfactory proof of obtaining a sales tax number for each location at which fireworks sales will be had and they will provide proof that annual sales tax returns have been filed for each location located inside the city within 15 days of filing sales tax returns. 
(b)  Permits are not transferable. 
(c)  A permit shall be valid only from June 20 through July 5 or December 10 through January 2, unless you have a permanent building that meets zoning regulations for retail sales, and then an annual permit may be used for both the above dates. 
(d)  The city shall charge a fee of $1.00 per square foot, minimum of $1,200.00 for any temporary tent or structure for the issuance of each semiannual permit provided for in this section. 
(e)  Application for a permit to sell fireworks in the city shall be submitted to the codes director no later than five working days prior to the date on which the applicant desires to begin making sales. 
(f)  An application must be filed for each location and shall contain the following: 
(1)  Name, address, and telephone number of applicant. The applicant must be the natural person who will be responsible for sales. The applicant's name or company name shall also be the same as the name on the state fire marshal permit. Names of all partners or persons sharing more than ten percent of the profit shall be disclosed on the application. The applicant shall be liable for all violations of this article by persons under their supervision. 
(2)  A copy of the state fire marshal permit. 
(3)  Evidence that general liability insurance has been obtained by applicant naming the City of Mt. Juliet, Tennessee as additional insured for at least $1,000,000.00 for each occurrence, whether in respect to bodily injury liability or property damage liability or bodily injury and property damage liability combined. 
(4)  The location where the applicant will conduct the business of selling fireworks. 
(5)  Cleanup deposits of $500.00 per location shall be paid by applicant, which shall be refunded after the fireworks season inspection, or used by the city to clean up the retail fireworks site, if needed. 
(6)  A copy of the tent flame retardant letter on all tents must be provided. 
(7)  Evidence of working fire extinguishers, which must be easily accessible and in plain view. Tents exceeding 30 feet by 40 feet (1,200 square feet) must have a minimum of two extinguishers on site. 
(8)  Site plan including: 
a.  Dimension of the lot; 
b.  Dimension and location of tent; 
c.  Location of adjacent structures; 
d.  Location of parking and number of spaces provided. 
(9)  Assurance of a 20-foot setback from extreme outer edge of the lane of travel to the tent or signage. To be measured from the edge of the tent side or overhang of the top, not to include ropes, tie-downs or other appendages used to secure tents. 
(Ord. No. 2012-01, § 1, 1-23-2012)  
Sec. 10-188. - Permit revocation. 
The code official shall be authorized to revoke any permit upon failure to correct any of the following conditions within 24 hours after notification: 
(1)  In the event that the permittee or the permittee's operator violates any lawful rule, regulation, or order of the codes director of the city. 
(2)  In the event that the permittee's application contains any false or untrue statements. 
(3)  In the event the permittee fails to timely file and/or pay any report, tax, fee, fine or charge. 
(4)  In the event the permittee or the permittee's operator violates this article or statute. 
(5)  In the event the permittee or the permittee's operator incurs multiple city or state offenses, the city may not grant approval for said company to operate at any location within the corporate city limits and possibly withhold approval not to exceed two years from fireworks' season in which violation occurred. 
(Ord. No. 2012-01, § 1, 1-23-2012)  
Sec. 10-189. - Permissible fireworks. 
It is unlawful for any individual to possess, sell, or use within the city, or ship into the city, except as provided in this article, any pyrotechnics commonly known as fireworks other than the following permissible items: 
(1)  Those items now or hereafter classified as DOT Class C common fireworks; or 
(2)  Those items that comply with the construction, chemical composition, and labeling regulations promulgated by the United States Consumer Product Safety Commission and permitted for use by the general public under its regulations. 
(Ord. No. 2012-01, § 1, 1-23-2012)  
Sec. 10-190. - Sale of fireworks. 
Fireworks and related legal accessories may be sold within the city only from June 20 through July 5 and December 10 through January 2. All signs must comply with Article 11, Sign Regulations, of the city zoning ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 2012-01, § 1, 1-23-2012)  
Sec. 10-191. - Unlawful sale and use of fireworks. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful to offer for sale or to sell any fireworks to children under the age of 18 years. 
Advisory signs shall be posted in plain view regarding minimum age to purchase fireworks. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful to offer for sale or to sell any fireworks to any intoxicated or seemingly irresponsible person. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful to explode or ignite fireworks within 600 feet of any church, hospital, funeral home, public or private school, or within 200 feet of where fireworks are stored, sold, or offered for sale. No person shall ignite or discharge any permissible articles of fireworks within or throw the same from a motor vehicle while within, nor shall any person place or throw any ignited article of fireworks into or at such a motor vehicle, or at or near any person or group of persons. 
(d)  It shall be unlawful for a user of fireworks to ignite fireworks on another person's private property unless permission is obtained from the owner or occupant of the property. Fireworks shall not be launched or fired onto the property of persons who have not given permission.
