(c)  Robert's Rules of Order. In the absence of specific rules to the contrary set by the board, Robert's Rules of Order shall govern all meetings of the board. 
(d)  Recordkeeping. The board shall keep a written or electronically recorded record of its meetings, recommendations, findings and determinations. The original of these records shall be maintained by the director of parks and recreation, and a copy of these records shall be provided to the city recorder. 
(Ord. No. 2009-04, § 1(12-4-110), 1-26-2009)  
Sec. 24-126. - Ethics. 
The members of the board shall be subject to the requirements of chapter 2, article XII, pertaining to the city's code of ethics. Copies of chapter 2, article XII, pertaining to the code of ethics, along with subsequent amendments thereto, shall be made available to the members of the board. 
(Ord. No. 2009-04, § 1(12-4-111), 1-26-2009)  
Secs. 24-12724-150. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 3. - DIRECTOR OF PARKS AND RECREATION 
 
Sec. 24-151. - Qualifications and duties. 
The director of parks and recreation (the director) shall have training and/or experience in parks and recreation administration. The director shall be the chief operational and administrative officer responsible for the management of all public parks, playgrounds and other recreational areas and responsible for the implementation and direction of a comprehensive recreational program for the city. The director shall be an employee of the city and shall report to and be supervised by the city manager. The director shall perform such duties as may be assigned to him by the city manager, including, but not limited to, assisting the board in fulfilling its duties under this article. 
(Code 1997, §§ 12-4-201, 12-4-202; Ord. No. 2009-04, § 1(12-4-201), 1-26-2009)  
Secs. 24-15224-170. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 4. - PARKS RULES AND REGULATIONS 
 
Sec. 24-171. - In general. 
(a)  It shall be illegal to procure, aid, or cause to occur any act prohibited by this article. 
(b)  The parks director shall publish copies of these rules and regulation in each park, community center, or other recreational facility. 
(Code 1997, § 12-4-301; Ord. No. 2009-04, § 1(12-4-301), 1-26-2009)  
Sec. 24-172. - Prohibited uses. 
(a)  No person shall damage, deface or destroy park property. 
(b)  No person shall litter in the park. 
(c)  No person shall dispose of household trash in park trash receptacles. 
(d)  No person shall advertise products or services in the park using either signs or sound. This prohibition shall not apply to signs affixed to vehicles used primarily to transport people to the park or to advertising affixed to uniforms or clothing. 
(e)  No person shall gamble in the parks. 
(f)  No person shall bring alcoholic beverages, drugs, firearms, fireworks, BB guns, air rifles, bows or arrows into a park, except as provided herein. This provision shall not apply to law enforcement officers. Persons may bring legally licensed handguns into the parks. 
(g)  No person shall perform routine vehicle maintenance (such as changing the oil) in the park. 
(h)  No person shall disobey an official regulatory or directional sign. 
(i)  No person, except a park employee, shall place a sign in the park. 
(j)  No person shall drive a motorized vehicle off of the road. 
(k)  There will be no fighting within any city parks. 
(l)  Violations of this section are subject to exclusion/expulsion from all city parks and, depending on the severity of the violation, may be subject to criminal or civil prosecution. 
(Code 1997, § 12-4-302; Ord. No. 2009-04, § 1(12-4-302), 1-26-2009)  
Sec. 24-173. - Regulated uses. 
The following uses are subject to permit or other restrictions: 
(1)  Persons with permits or scheduled reservations of ball diamonds, tennis courts, football fields, soccer fields, picnic areas and other facilities subject to scheduled use shall have superior right to use such facilities and no person shall interfere with such rights. 
(2)  No person shall sell any food or product without a permit. Such sales shall be confined to the concession stands. 
(3)  No person shall build a fire in a park except in metal grills. 
(4)  No person shall sleep in the park or remain in the park overnight. 
(5)  No person shall operate a powered model airplane or model vehicle except in prescribed areas outlined by the parks director. 
(6)  No person shall bring a horse or farm animals into the park without a permit. 
(7)  Dogs and cats are permitted in the park, but shall be restrained by a leash. Other pets are prohibited without a permit. 
(8)  No person shall operate a vehicle in the park at a speed in excess of 15 miles per hour. No person shall operate a vehicle such as a go-cart or offroad motorcycle off of areas designated for such vehicles. 
(Code 1997, § 12-4-303; Ord. No. 2009-04, § 1(12-4-303), 1-26-2009)  
Sec. 24-174. - Free community access time. 
(a)  The director shall designate ten hours per week as free community access time. During the hours designated as free community access time, citizens of the city shall be allowed to use the community center (with the exception of the weight room) without paying the currently applicable daily user fee. No reservations for facilities shall be taken during this time. 
(b)  The scheduled free community access time may, at the discretion of the director or the city manager, be preempted by special events. Such special events or functions shall be noticed to the public by posting at the community center and through such other methods as deemed necessary by the director or the city manager. 
(Code 1997, § 12-4-305; Ord. No. 2003-15, 3-24-2003; Ord. No. 2009-04, § 1(12-4-305), 1-26-2009)  
Sec. 24-175. - Use of amphitheater at Charlie Daniels Park. 
Applications, as set forth in this section, including terms and conditions for use of the amphitheater at Charlie Daniels Park will be used for taking reservations for the amphitheater. Application instructions and terms and conditions for amphitheater use are as follows: 
(1)  The base application fee is due on the date of application, subject to refund if application is refused. 
(2)  Applications for general use are accepted on the first business day in January each year. The parks and recreation department have first priority in scheduling events in all parks and facilities. All dates are reserved on first come, first served basis. Events dates are not confirmed until all related fees are paid. 
(3)  If the event will include elements added to park facilities, such as tents, rides, etc., a certificate of insurance must be submitted with this application. The policy must be in force for the duration of the event and be issued by an insurance company licensed to do business in the state, specifying public liability and property damage insurance with a single limit of not less than $1,000,000.00, naming the city and the city parks and recreation department as additionally insured. No event will be permitted unless this certificate has been received. 
(4)  Any changes to the event described in the application must be submitted in writing to the park office. Any aspect of the event not fully described in the application or an addendum submitted in accordance with this section will not be allowed in the parks facility. 
(5)  All events in city parks must fit with the following guidelines: 
a.  The proposed activity or use of the park must not unreasonably interfere with or detract from the public's enjoyment of the park. 
b.  The proposed activity or use will not unreasonably interfere with or detract from the promotion of public health, welfare, safety and recreation. 
c.  The proposed activity or use will not include or promote violence, crime or disorderly conduct. 
d.  The proposed activity or use will not entail extraordinary or burdensome expense or police operations by the city. 
(6)  All special events to be held in parks requesting permission to have amplified music will be considered by the parks department on a case-by-case basis. A park staff member to ensure proper sound levels will monitor the event. The staff member shall have the authority to direct a reduction of sound levels or to stop the performance if deemed necessary and in the best interest of the parks department and the persons in the immediate neighborhood. 
(7)  Prior to but not earlier than six hours before the event, the event holder must perform an inspection of the facility and must report in writing to the parks department the presence of any damage or trash on the premises. All damage evident or trash remaining on the premises after the event and not previously and specifically reported to the parks department as required in this subsection, will be considered to have resulted from the event and must be rectified at the sole expense of the event holder. 
(8)  It is the event holder's responsibility to return the park to the condition it was in prior to the permitted event or pay fees related to returning the property to condition prior to event. Event holders are responsible for all cleanups after each event. The parks department reserves the right to require, of any event holder, a security deposit. The posting of a deposit does not relieve the event holder from the responsibility for performing all cleanups and correcting all damage relating to the event as well as responsibility of loss of property. The event holder agrees to reimburse the parks department for all costs incurred in performing cleanups and repairs which, in the judgment of the department, the event holder has failed to perform. Cleanup and repair cost shall accrue at the rate of $30.00 per manhour. If cleanup or repair takes place on a holiday, the cost shall accrue at the rate of $50.00 per manhour. These rates do not include any additional cost of cleaning supplies, basic landscaping materials and the like. The event holder's deposit will be applied to cleanup and repair cost accruing under this subsection. 
(9)  The parks department reserves the right to require event holders to provide the following security at their expense: off-duty police officers and/or chaperones as the department deems necessary to ensure the safety of the public and park facilities. Three security personnel and their phone numbers shall be listed on the application. During the course of the event all security personnel must remain at the event or the event will be cancelled. The requirement in this subsection will be strictly enforced. 
(10)  No alcoholic beverages or drugs are allowed in park facility. 
(11)  All signage, advertising, publicity, exhibits or displays advertising an event and posted on city property must have prior approval by the parks department. All signs must comply with chapter 20, pertaining to signs. 
(12)  All events must end no later than 11:00 p.m. However, the event still shall be subject to section 16-22, pertaining to noise. 
(13)  Appropriate park personnel and members of the parks and police department must be provided access to event upon request in order to monitor event activities and ensure compliance with ordinances, rules and regulations. 
(14)  The parks department has the authority to revoke any permit for any violation of any of the rules set forth in this section or upon good cause shown. 
(15)  In the event of willful noncompliance with any provision of these terms and conditions, the parks department can in its sole discretion ban any event sponsor or professional event organizer, promoter or the like from further sponsorship or promotion of any event in the park facility for a period of two years. 
(16)  By submitting an application, the event organizer agrees to the following terms: 
a.  The event organizer will indemnify and hold harmless the city and the city parks department from any and all claims, damages, cost and attorney fees for injuries or damages arising in part or in whole from the organization's use of park facilities and described in the permit application, and any claims, damages, costs and attorney fees arising from any failure of the organization, its officers, employees and agents to observe applicable laws, ordinances, rules and regulations. 
b.  The event organizer assumes all risk and responsibility for any dangerous or defective conditions on the grounds of the facility, whether known or unknown. 
c.  The event organizer agrees to restore the park facility to the condition in which it existed prior to the event. 
d.  The application shall set forth the entire agreement of the parties. 
e.  The individual executing the application on behalf of the event organizer affirms that he is authorized to do so. 
f.  All events are smoke-free events, the only exception being when designated smoking areas are provided. 
g.  No modifications of the application shall be valid unless in writing and signed by the director or other authorized representative of the parks department. 
h.  State law shall govern any dispute arising from the application, and any suit relating in any way to the application shall be brought in a court of competent jurisdiction in the county. 
i.  All applicants must be at least 18 years of age. 
j.  No pyrotechnics of any kind will be allowed. 
k.  In case of inclement weather, deposits and fees will be refunded. 
l.  The fee schedule as set forth in section 24-176. 
(17)  Applications shall be submitted to the following location: Mt. Juliet Community Center, P.O. Box 256, Mt. Juliet, Tennessee 37121. 
(Ord. No. 2003-20, § 1, 5-12-2003)

Chapter 26 - TAXATION  
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 26-1. - Fiscal year. 
The fiscal year of the city shall begin on July 1 of each year and end on June 30 of the following year. 
(Code 1997, § 6-1-101; Ord. No. 73-5, 6-7-1973)  
Sec. 26-2. - Official depositories of city funds. 
The following banks are hereby designated official depositories for funds of the City of Mt. Juliet: 
(1)  Wilson Bank and Trust; and 
(2)  State of TN  Local Government Investment Pool (LGIP). 
(Code 1997, § 6-1-102; Ord. No. 2007-49, 10-22-2007; Ord. No. 2008-15, §§ 13, 3-10-2008; Ord. No. 2008-59, §§ 13, 11-24-2008; Ord. No. 2012-11, §§ 1, 2, 2-27-2012)  
Sec. 26-3. - Line item budget guidelines. 
(a)  The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Emergency expenditures include, but are not limited to, expenditures necessary to immediately protect the public health, safety or welfare or expenditures that are time-sensitive. 
(b)  Expenditures must be spent for the purposes designated in the operating budget. Each month, the city manager shall submit a resolution (omnibus resolution) for approval by the city commission that includes an itemization of all proposed intradepartmental line item transfers in excess of $2,000.00, provided that, in the event of an emergency, the city manager may make such intradepartmental transfer absent prior approval by the city commission. Any such emergency transfers shall be included for informational purposes in the next monthly omnibus resolution. 
(c)  Capital expenditures must be spent for the purposes designated in the capital outlay budget unless the city commission has approved a change in the capital outlay budget in the monthly omnibus resolution, provided that, in the event of an emergency, the city manager may make expenditures not in conformance with the capital outlay budget absent prior approval by the city commission. Any such emergency expenditure shall be included for informational purposes in the next monthly omnibus resolution. 
(d)  All routine purchases, payments for services, and payroll disbursements will not be affected by this section. Journal entries or standard entries made in accordance with generally accepted governmental accounting principles shall not be affected by this section. 
(Ord. No. 2006-07, § 1, 3-13-2006)  
Secs. 26-426-24. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - WHOLESALE BEER TAX 
 
Sec. 26-25. - To be collected. 
The recorder is hereby directed to take appropriate action to ensure payment to the city of the wholesale beer tax levied by the Wholesale Beer Tax Act as set out in T.C.A. § 57-6-101 et seq. 
(Code 1997, § 6-2-101)  
Secs. 26-2626-53. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - PRIVILEGE TAXES 
 
Sec. 26-54. - Levied. 
A tax is hereby levied on all vocations, occupations, and businesses declared by the general laws of the state to be privileges taxable by municipalities, an annual privilege tax in the maximum amount allowed by state laws. The tax provided for in the state's Business Tax Act as set out in T.C.A. § 67-4-701 et seq. are hereby expressly enacted, ordained and levied on the businesses, business activities, vocations, and occupations carried on within the city at the rates and in the manner prescribed by the act. 
(Code 1997, § 6-3-101; Ord. No. 83-22, § 1, 9-5-1983)  
Sec. 26-55. - License required. 
A license is required and no person shall exercise any such privilege within the city without a currently effective privilege license which shall be issued by the recorder to each applicant thereof upon the applicant's payment of the appropriate privilege tax. 
(Code 1997, § 6-3-102; Ord. No. 83-22, § 1, 9-5-1983)  
Sec. 26-56. - Hotel/motel tax. 
(a)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Bed and breakfast means establishments [that] are small businesses often located in a quaint setting or in a small structure with residential appearance. 
Consideration means the consideration charged, whether or not received, for the occupancy in a hotel valued in money, goods, labor or otherwise, including all receipts, cash, credits, property and services of any kind or nature without any deduction therefrom whatsoever. 
Hostle means an owner-occupied detached dwelling in which the owner rents rooms to temporary residents or travelers, such as college students, for the purpose of offering short-term accommodations. 
Hotel means any structure or space, or any portion thereof, which is occupied or intended or designed for occupancy by transients for dwelling, lodging or sleeping purposes, and includes any hotel, inn, tourist camp, tourist cabin, motel or any place in which rooms, lodgings or accommodations are furnished to transients for a consideration. 
Occupancy means the use or possession, or the right to use or possession, of any room, lodgings or accommodations in any hotel. 
Operator means the person operating the hotel whether as owner, lessee or otherwise. 
Persons means any individual, firm, partnership, joint venture, association, social club, fraternal organization, joint stock company, estate, trust, business trust, receiver, trustee, syndicate, governmental units or any other group or combination acting as a unit; and 
Transient means any person who exercises occupancy or is entitled to occupancy of any rooms, lodgings or accommodations in a hotel for a period of less than 30 continuous days. 
(b)  Permit required. No person will conduct, keep, manage, operate or cause to be conducted, kept, managed or operated, either as owner, lessor, agent or attorney, any hotel in the city without having obtained a permit from the city recorder or his designee to do so. 
(c)  Fee. The fee for each hotel permit will be $25.00. 
(d)  Permit not transferable. No permit issued under this section shall be transferred or assigned. 
(e)  Permit duration. Hotel permits shall be issued annually and shall expire on December 31 of each year. 
(f)  Register required; availability for inspection. Every person to whom a hotel permit is issued under this section shall at all times keep a standard hotel register, in which shall be inscribed the names of all guests renting or occupying rooms or accommodations in his hotel. Such register shall include: 
(1)  The name of persons renting a room or accommodations; 
(2)  The number of the room or accommodation which the guest is to occupy; and 
(3)  The time during which such room or accommodation is rented. 
The register shall be open to inspection at all times to the city recorder or his designee. 
(g)  Privilege tax levied; use. 
(1)  Pursuant to the provisions of T.C.A. § 67-4-1401 et seq., hereafter referred to as the Hotel Tax Act, there is hereby levied a privilege of occupancy in any hotel of each transient. From and after the operative date of this section the rate of the levy shall be four percent of the consideration charged by the operator. This privilege tax shall be collected by the hotel operator pursuant to the Hotel Tax Act. The hotel must disclose the amount of the tax to each invoice provided to guests. 
(2)  The proceeds received from this tax shall be available for the city's parks and recreation funds and may be expended for the purposes of buying, leasing, or otherwise acquiring an interest in real or personal property or equipment to promote recreational activity in the city. Proceeds of this tax may not be used to provide a subsidy in any form to any hotel or motel. 
(3)  The finance director shall be designated as the authorized collector to administer and enforce this section and the Hotel Tax Act. 
(h)  Remitting the tax. Remittance of the tax collected by the hotel operator to the city shall occur on or before than the 20th day of each month for the preceding month. When remitting the tax levied, the operator must submit a monthly report, under oath, on a form approved by the board of commissioners, and may report and deduct two percent of the amount due as compensation to the hotel operator for the accounting expense for remitting the tax. 
(i)  Interest and penalty for late payment. The hotel operator shall be liable to pay interest on delinquent hotel taxes, to be paid from the due date for remittance at the rate of 12 percent per annum, and is liable for a penalty of one percent for each month or fraction of a month that the hotel tax is delinquent. 
(j)  Audit and reporting of taxes. The city manager shall cause to be conducted an annual audit of each hotel operator and shall report on the audits made on a quarterly basis to the board of commissioners. 
(k)  Records requirement. The hotel operator must keep records of occupancy and taxes collected and remitted pursuant to this section for three years. The city may inspect these records at any time. 
(l)  Challenge and dispute of tax. The city manager is hereby designated as the municipal officer against whom suit may be brought when a dispute arises as to the amount of hotel/motel tax to be remitted by an operator. 
(m)  Violation. In addition to interest and penalties described in subsection (i) of this section, knowingly refusing to collect or remit the tax is a Class A misdemeanor, punishable by a fine for each day that the operator knowingly refused to collect or remit the tax. The fine for each offense shall be $50.00 per day. 
(Code 1997, § 6-3-201; Ord. No. 2007-60, 12-10-2007; Ord. No. 2008-20, § 1, 4-28-2008; Ord. No. 2014-39, § 1, 5-12-2014; Ord. No. 2015-09, § 1, 2-23-2015; Ord. No. 2017-35, 6-12-2017)  
Sec. 26-57. - Concerning hotel/motel tax further defined. 
(1)  Hotels and motels shall include a minimum of 100 guest rooms with each room accessed from an interior corridor and not from an exterior parking lot or entrance. Hotels and motels must have a lobby, which is staffed, 24 hours, 7-days-a-week and offers daily complimentary maid service. In addition, all hotels and motels shall have a swimming pool and a fitness center. All hotels and motels must provide the following four amenities: 
(a)  A full hot breakfast offered to the public for a fee. 
(b)  A minimum of 3,000 square feet of indoor common area open to guests and the general public, including lobbies, but excluding guest rooms, corridors, meeting rooms, swimming pools, guest room corridors, or health club facilities. 
(c)  A business center located in a separate room adjacent to the lobby and measuring at least 450 square feet. The business center shall contain computers, Wi-Fi availability, printers, and associated office equipment. The business center will be furnished with desks and office chairs, and is available to hotel guests at all times. 
(d)  A minimum of 1,800 square feet of dedicated meeting space that is of ballroom quality and available to rent to the general public and guests of the hotel for compensation. The meeting space should be one contiguous space that can be divided with temporary soundproof wall (minimum of STC rating of 45). 
(2)  Bed and breakfast and hostels establishments are not considered hotels and motels for the purpose of this section. Bed and breakfast establishments are small businesses often located in a quaint setting or in a small structure with a residential appearance. 
(Ord. No. 2015-09, § 1, 2-23-2015; Ord. No. 2016-2, § 1, 1-11-2016)  
Secs. 26-5826-85. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IV. - LOCAL SALES TAX 
 
Sec. 26-86. - Levied. 
As authorized by T.C.A. §§ 67-6-70167-6-712, as amended, there is levied a tax in the same manner and on the same privileges subject to the Retailers' Sales Tax Act, T.C.A. § 67-6-101 et seq., as amended, which are exercised in the city. The tax is levied on all such privileges at a rate of three-fourths of one percent. Penalties and interest for delinquencies shall be the same as provided or authorized by state statutes. 
(Code 1997, § 6-4-101)  
Sec. 26-87. - When collections to begin. 
If a majority of those voting in the election required by T.C.A. § 67-6-706 vote for the provisions of this article, collection of the tax levied by this article shall begin on the first day of the month occurring 30 or more days after the county election commission makes its official canvass of the election returns. 
(Code 1997, § 6-4-102; Ord. No. 83-15, § 2)  
Sec. 26-88. - Collection by department of revenue. 
It having been determined by the department of revenue of the state that it is feasible for this tax to be collected by that department, this determination being evidenced by local option sales and use tax rules and regulations heretofore promulgated by the department of revenue, the department shall collect the tax concurrently with the collection of the state tax in the same manner as the state tax is collected in accordance with the rules and regulations promulgated by the department. The mayor of the city is hereby authorized to: 
(1)  Contract with the department of revenue for the collection of the tax by the department; 
(2)  Provide in the contract that the department of revenue for the collection of the tax by the department; and 
(3)  Provide in the contract that the department may deduct from the tax collected, a reasonable amount or percentage to cover the expense of the administration and collection of the tax. 
(Code 1997, § 6-4-103; Ord. No. 83-15, § 3)  
Sec. 26-89. - Suits for recovery of illegal taxes. 
In the event the tax is collected by the department of revenue, suits for the recovery of any tax illegally assessed or collected shall be brought against the mayor of the city. 
(Code 1997, § 6-4-104; Ord. No. 83-15, § 4)  
Sec. 26-90. - Base to which tax applicable. 
The base upon which the tax is applicable shall be the maximum amount allowed by law. 
(Code 1997, § 6-4-105; Ord. No. 83-19, § 2) 
State Law reference Base for sales tax, T.C.A. § 67-6-702(a)(1) and (2).  
Sec. 26-91. - Increase automatic. 
Future increases in the base beginning on the dates specified in this Code shall be automatic and shall not require further action of the board of commissioners of the city. 
(Code 1997, § 6-4-106; Ord. No. 83-19, § 3)  
Sec. 26-92. - Tax rate unaffected by increase in base. 
Nothing herein contained shall be construed to increase the local option sales tax rate heretofore in effect in the city. 
(Code 1997, § 6-4-107; Ord. No. 83-19, § 4)  
Secs. 26-9326-112. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE V. - IMPACT FEES 
 
Sec. 26-113. - Imposition, calculation and collection. 
(a)  Except as provided in this article and any amendment to this article, the city may impose impact fees as a condition of approval of all new development projects covered by this article. The fee will be imposed based on the square feet of floor area. Floor area shall mean the total of the gross horizontal area of all floors, including usable basements and cellars, below the roof and within the outer surface of the main walls of principal or accessory buildings or the center lines of party wall separating such buildings or portions thereof. 
(b)  The base fee amount of each residential development shall be calculated annually and adopted by the board of commissioners by resolution not to exceed the maximum fees allowed by law. The fee is set at $0.50 per gross square foot of new residential development and may be amended by resolution on an annual basis as provided for in this article. 
(c)  Impact fees shall be collected by the city engineer or, at his direction, at the time and as a condition for issuance of a building permit. 
(d)  Impact fees shall be expended for: 
(1)  Streets and parks; 
(2)  Proposals for changes in the boundaries of benefit areas; and 
(3)  Proposals for changes to impact fee rates and schedules. 
(Code 1997, § 6-5-101; Ord. No. 98-16, 6-5-1998; Ord. No. 98-37, 10-5-1998)  
Sec. 26-114. - Appeals. 
(a)  Any person or concern affected by the imposition of an impact fee may challenge the imposition of a fee imposed pursuant to this article by filing with the city clerk a written notice of appeal with a full statement of the grounds and an appeal fee of $200.00 or such other amounts as may be fixed from time to time by resolution of the board of commissioners. The city may continue processing the development application if the notice of appeal is accompanied with a bond or other security in an amount equal to the impact fee. 
(b)  The appellant bears the burden of demonstrating that the amount of the fee was not calculated according to the procedures established in the ordinance or by resolution adopting fees. 
(c)  At a regular meeting following the filing of the appeal, the board of commissioners shall fix a time and place for hearing the appeal, and the city recorder shall mail notice of the hearing to the appellant at the address given in the notice of appeal. The hearing shall be conducted at the time and place stated in the notice, and the determination of the board of commissioners shall be announced at the conclusion of the hearing or at the next regular meeting of the board of commissioners. The determination of the board of commissioners shall be final. 
(Code 1997, § 6-5-102; Ord. No. 98-16, 6-5-1998; Ord. No. 98-37, 10-5-1998)  
Secs. 26-11526-141. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VI. - PLANNING/ZONING FEES 
 
Sec. 26-142. - Action to applicant. 
Revenue-neutral fees shall be charged each applicant presenting a subdivision of land, a change in zoning classification or a site development plan for approval. 
(Code 1997, § 6-6-102)  
Sec. 26-143. - When payments are due. 
Prior to initiating a response to any subdivision plat submitted pursuant to the subdivision regulations or to any change in zoning classification or any site development plan submitted pursuant to requirements of the zoning ordinance, the applicant shall pay to the city the fees established herein to cover the expected direct costs associated with processing of such application and the annual administration of these regulations. Full cost recovery (revenue neutral) fees set forth herein shall be charged each applicant presenting a subdivision of land, a change in zoning classification or a site development plan for approval. 
(Code 1997, § 6-6-103)  
Sec. 26-144. - Accountability. 
The city shall maintain careful records of its costs of administering these regulations and shall, by amendment to the regulations, endeavor to match application fees with average associated costs on a revenue neutral basis, reflecting the city's cost of administration experience hereunder. 
(Code 1997, § 6-6-104)  
Sec. 26-145. - What fees are to cover. 
(a)  The full cost of administration to be recovered shall consist of the following two components: 
(1)  The direct cost of the administration of the subdivision regulations and zoning ordinance, whether by city personnel or professional firms under contract to the city to perform such services, dealing with the specific application on a timely and efficient, yet thorough, manner; 
(2)  The reasonable costs, prorated among all applicants during the year, prorated by acreage and/or number of lots potentially constructed on the applicant's site should the application be approved, to be shared among all applicants of the land use planning for the regional area and the administration of the subdivision regulations and zoning ordinance, including, but not limited to, the following costs: 
a.  Per diem salaries, if any, of the planning commission; 
b.  Regional geophysical data assessments and associated land use planning reflecting; 
c.  Floodplains; 
d.  Traffic management; 
e.  Regional utility service planning; 
f.  Legal costs associated with drafting and administering these regulations and legal defense of the city and its officials arising as a result of actions taken pursuant to the regulations; 
g.  Population growth forecasting; 
h.  Aerial photography; 
i.  Maintenance of land use management computer data bases; and 
j.  All other actual costs to the city associated with administration of these regulations. 
(b)  A development and construction fee shall be hereinafter assessed against each new construction project/development in the city in order to defray the costs incurred by the city for services incident thereto, including cost of employing a road and street inspector. 
(c)  The cost to the city of providing such service shall be borne by developers of new construction projects in the city. 
(d)  The public works director shall determine the amount of the fee to be paid, which shall be a revenue-neutral, prorated amount necessary to fund inspection based upon all new construction/development projects in the city. 
(Code 1997, § 6-6-105; Ord. No. 2004-13, 4-5-2004)  
Sec. 26-146. - Not connected to sewer fees. 
The fees shall be paid at the time an application is made and as a condition for the processing of any application. The fees charged in this article are in addition to and separate from any fees charged for sewer development, sewer use or sewer rate fees as set forth in city ordinances. 
(Code 1997, § 6-6-107; Ord. No. 98-18, 6-15-1998)

Chapter 28 - TRAFFIC AND VEHICLES  
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Secs. 28-128-20. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - CITY TRAFFIC COMMISSION 
 
Sec. 28-21. - Established. 
There is hereby established within the city a management entity to be known as the city traffic commission. The authority is established pursuant to the provisions of T.C.A. §§ 6-19-101 et seq., 7-51-1001 and 7-56-101 et seq. The traffic commission is vested with all powers provided and authorized pursuant to this Code and state statutes. In addition to these powers, the traffic commission shall have authority to: 
(1)  Approve or deny decisions made by city staff as the result of a warrants study for a new traffic control sign or device or a warrants study for a revision to an existing traffic control sign or device; 
(2)  Exempt streets or alleys, or sections of streets or alleys, from the requirements of section 28-193; and 
(3)  Otherwise establish parking requirements and designations within the city. 
(Code 1997, § 5-9-101; Ord. No. 98-23, 7-6-1998; Ord. No. 98-37, 10-5-1998; Ord. No. 2008-47, § 2, 8-11-2008; Ord. No. 2012-30, § 1, 5-29-2012; Ord. No. 2014-55, § 1, 7-14-2014)  
Sec. 28-22. - Membership. 
The traffic commission shall consist of four members who are residents of the city to be appointed by the mayor and confirmed by the board of commissioners. The members of said commission shall be bona fide residents of the city at the time of their appointment and shall remain residents of the city or the area comprising said city during the term of their appointment. In addition to the four members set forth in this section, the chief of police shall serve as a member with the right to vote and the city manager shall serve as member but shall have no vote except in case of a tie. The members of the first commission appointed shall take office as of the date of their appointment and qualification. The chief of police and city manager shall serve as permanent members. The remaining members shall serve for terms of three years, provided that one member shall be appointed for a term of one year from the date of appointment, one for two years and the remaining two for three years. 
(Code 1997, § 5-9-102; Ord. No. 98-23, 7-6-1998; Ord. No. 98-37, 10-5-1998)  
Sec. 28-23. - Duties. 
(a)  The traffic commission shall organize by selecting among its membership a chairperson, a vice-chairperson and a secretary. Each shall serve in such capacity for a term of one year or until their successors have been chosen for like terms. 
(b)  It shall be the duty of the secretary to keep all records, conduct official correspondence and generally supervise the clerical work of the commission. Said secretary is authorized to draw upon the employees of the city for such assistance as may be necessary in the performance of his duties. 
(c)  The traffic commission shall hold regular sessions at such times as it shall establish in its rules. The initial organizational meeting shall be called by the city manager and the traffic commission shall organize and set the times of its regular meetings. Special sessions may be called by the chairperson or at the request of any member thereof, provided that notice of such special session has been mailed to each member at least 24 hours before the time set, provided further that the announcement shall constitute sufficient notice. 
(d)  All hearings of the traffic commission shall be held at city hall and shall be open to the public. The traffic commission shall keep minutes of its proceedings, showing the vote of each member. Three voting members shall constitute a quorum. 
(e)  No item may be voted upon without first holding a public hearing and signage placed at the location notifying the public. Signage shall be displayed no more than 60 days. The notice shall appear for at least 30 days immediately preceding the meeting of the traffic commission. The sign shall contain such information as date, time, location of hearing and summary. 
(Code 1997, § 5-9-103; Ord. No. 98-23, 7-6-1998; Ord. No. 98-37, 10-5-1998; Ord. No. 2014-55, § 2, 7-14-2014)  
Sec. 28-24. - Agenda guidelines. 
(a)  Appeal items shall be received by the city recorder at least 60 days prior to the quarterly meeting of the Mt. Juliet Traffic Commission. Meetings are held the third Tuesday of the first month of each quarter (if needed): (January; April; July; October). 
(b)  Other agenda items shall be received by the city recorder at least 30 days prior to the regular scheduled quarterly meeting. 
(c)  Any item that is voted on by the Mt. Juliet Traffic Commission in a regular scheduled meeting or in a special called meeting of the commission shall not be eligible for reconsideration by the Mt. Juliet Traffic Commission for a period of one year after the meeting in which the vote occurred. 
(Ord. No. 2012-30, § 2, 5-29-2012; Ord. No. 2014-55, § 3, 7-14-2014)  
Secs. 28-2528-49. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - TRAFFIC REGULATIONS 
 
Sec. 28-50. - Authorized emergency vehicles. 
Authorized emergency vehicles shall be fire department vehicles, police vehicles, and such ambulances and other emergency vehicles as are designated by the chief of police. 
(Code 1997, § 9-1-101; Ord. No. 74-9, § 1(1), 6-20-1974)  
Sec. 28-51. - Operation of authorized emergency vehicles. 
(a)  Pursuit. Pursuing fleeing traffic offenders presents some shortterm danger to other motorists. Failure to pursue fleeing traffic offenders breeds a disregard for law and the authority of the police to enforce the law, which presents a longterm danger to other motorists. A police officer driving a police vehicle in pursuit of an actual or suspected violator of the law may deviate from normal legal driving rules after weighing the need for haste against the dangers to other people using the roads. In weighing the need for haste, police officers shall weigh the seriousness of the violation of person pursued. They shall also weigh the public danger of people escaping at will from violations by merely fleeing. In pursuing someone merely for violating a traffic law, they shall consider the need for high-speed pursuit once they have obtained a license number. 
(b)  Fire and ambulance emergency runs. The driver of an ambulance or fire engine shall obey all driving laws under normal conditions, as for example returning from a fire call, but may deviate from the driving laws in an emergency when it appears to the driver that the deviation can be done safely and it appears to the driver that the benefits of the deviation outweigh the risk to the public. 
(Code 1997, § 9-1-113) 
State Law reference See Haynes v. Hamilton County , 883 S.W.2d. 606 (1994) for liability for accidents which occur during a chase. See Ezell v. Cockrell , 902 S.W.2d. 394, holding there is no liability for failure to chase.  
Sec. 28-52. - Backing vehicles. 
The driver of a vehicle shall not back the vehicle unless such movement can be made with reasonable safety and without interfering with other traffic. 
(Code 1997, § 9-1-102; Ord. No. 74-9, § 1(22), 6-20-1974)  
Sec. 28-53. - Bicycles and off-street motor-driven vehicles. 
(a)  Every person riding or operating a bicycle, motorcycle, or motor scooter shall be subject to the provisions of all traffic ordinances, rules and regulations of the city applicable to the driver of other vehicles except as to those provisions which by their nature can have no application to bicycles, motorcycles or motor scooters. 
(b)  No person operating or riding a bicycle, motorcycle, or motor scooter shall ride other than upon or astride the permanent and regular seat attached thereto, nor shall the operator carry any other person upon such vehicle other than upon a firmly attached and regular seat. 
(c)  No bicycle, motor cycle, or motor scooter shall be used to carry more persons than the number for which it is designed and equipped. 
(d)  No person operating a bicycle, motorcycle, or motor scooter shall carry any package, bundle, or article which prevents the rider from keeping both hands upon handlebar. 
(e)  No person under the age of 16 years shall operate any motorcycle, motorbike, or motor scooter while any other person is a passenger upon the vehicle. 
(f)  No person shall operate or ride upon any motorcycle, motorbike, or motor scooter unless such person is equipped with and wearing on the head a safety helmet with a secured chin strap and suspension lining. The helmet shall conform to the type and design manufactured for the use of operators and riders of motor vehicles. 
(g)  No person shall operate or ride upon any off-street motor-driven or battery powered vehicle on any public street or alley at any time. All vehicles operated on public streets or alleys, other than bicycles, shall be equipped with headlight, taillight, turn signals and proper registration and license for such vehicle. 
(Code 1997, § 9-1-103; Ord. No. 74-9, § 1(27), 6-20-1974; Ord. No. 2003-53, § 1, 12-8-2003) 
State Law reference Bicycles, T.C.A. §§ 55-8-17155-8-173.  
Sec. 28-54. - Causing unnecessary noise. 
No person shall cause unnecessary noise by unnecessarily sounding the horn, racing the motor, or causing the screeching or squealing of the tires on any motor vehicle, or by playing any amplified electronic device audible at a distance of 25 feet from the vehicle. 
(Code 1997, § 9-1-104; Ord. No. 74-9, § 1(24), 6-20-1974)  
Sec. 28-55. - Clinging to vehicles in motion. 
No person traveling on any bicycle, coaster, sled or roller skates shall cling to or attach himself or his vehicle to any other moving vehicle upon any street, alley, or other public way or place. 
(Code 1997, § 9-1-105; Ord. No. 74-9, § 1(20), 6-20-1974)  
Sec. 28-56. - Damaging pavements. 
No person shall operate any vehicle on a city street which by reason of its weight or the character of its wheels or tracks is likely to damage the surface or foundation of a street. 
(Code 1997, § 9-1-106; Ord. No. 74-9, § 1(19), 6-20-1974)  
Sec. 28-57. - Driving on streets closed for repairs. 
Except for necessary access to property abutting thereon, no motor vehicle shall be driven upon any street that is barricaded or closed for repairs or other lawful purpose. 
(Code 1997, § 9-1-107; Ord. No. 74-9, § 1(6), 6-20-1974)  
Sec. 28-58. - Driving through funerals or other processions. 
Except when otherwise directed by a police officer, no driver of a vehicle shall drive between the vehicles comprising a funeral or other authorized procession while they are in motion and when such vehicles are conspicuously designated. 
(Code 1997, § 9-1-108; Ord. No. 74-9, § 1(18), 6-20-1974)  
Sec. 28-59. - Following emergency vehicles. 
No driver of any vehicle shall follow any authorized emergency vehicle running with lights or siren at a distance closer than 500 feet. No person shall park within 500 feet of a fire engine stopped to answer an alarm. 
(Code 1997, § 9-1-109; Ord. No. 74-9, § 1(4), 6-20-1974) 
State Law reference Following fire apparatus, T.C.A. § 55-8-168.  
Sec. 28-60. - General requirements for traffic control signs, etc. 
All traffic control signs, signals, markings, and devices shall conform to the latest revision of the Manual on Uniform Traffic Control Devices for Streets and Highways, published by the U.S. Department of Transportation, Federal Highway Administration and shall, so far as practical, be uniform as to type and location throughout the city. The manual may be obtained from the Superintendent of Documents, U.S. Government Printing Office, Washington, D.C. This section is not mandatory, it is merely directive. 
(Code 1997, § 9-1-110; Ord. No. 74-9, § 1(14), 6-20-1974)  
Sec. 28-61. - Compliance with traffic control devices; directions of police officer. 
(a)  No pedestrian or operator of any vehicle shall violate or fail to comply with any traffic control sign, signal, marking, or device placed or erected by the state or the city unless otherwise directed by a police officer. 
(b)  No pedestrian or operator of any vehicle willfully shall violate or fail to comply with the reasonable directions of any police officer. 
(Code 1997, § 9-1-111; Ord. No. 74-9, § 1(13), 6-20-1974) 
State Law reference Compliance with lawful orders or directions of police officers, T.C.A. § 55-8-1-4.  
Sec. 28-62. - Motor vehicle requirements. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to operate any motor vehicle within the corporate limits unless such vehicle is equipped with properly operating muffler, lights, brakes, horn, and such other equipment as is prescribed and required by chapter 9, title 55, of the Tennessee Code (T.C.A. § 55-9-101 et seq.). 
(Code 1997, § 9-1-112; Ord. No. 74-9, § 1(1), 6-20-1974)  
Sec. 28-63. - Passing. 
(a)  Except when overtaking and passing on the right is permitted, the driver of another vehicle proceeding in the same direction shall pass to the left thereof at a safe distance and shall not again drive to the right side of the street until safely clear of the overtaken vehicle. The driver of the overtaken vehicle shall give way to the right in favor of the overtaking vehicle on audible signal and shall not increase the speed of his vehicle until completely passed by the overtaking vehicle. 
(b)  When the street is wide enough, the driver of a vehicle may overtake and pass upon the right of another vehicle which is making or about to make a left turn. 
(c)  The driver of a vehicle may overtake and pass another vehicle proceeding in the same direction either upon the left or upon the right on a street of sufficient width for four or more lanes of moving traffic when such movement can be made in safety. 
(d)  No person shall dive off the pavement or upon the shoulder of the street in overtaking or passing on the right. 
(e)  When any vehicle has stopped at a marked crosswalk or at an intersection to permit a pedestrian to cross the street, no operator of any other vehicle approaching form the rear shall overtake and pass such stopped vehicle. 
(f)  No vehicle operator shall attempt to pass another vehicle proceeding in the same direction unless he can see that the way ahead is sufficiently clear and unobstructed to enable him to make the movement in safety. 
(Code 1997, § 9-1-114; Ord. No. 74-9, § 1(26), 6-20-1974) 
State Law reference Overtaking and passing, T.C.A. § 55-8-117; overtaking and passing on right, T.C.A. § 55-8-118.  
Sec. 28-64. - Presumption with respect to traffic control signs, etc. 
When a traffic control sign, signal, marking, or device has been placed, the presumption shall be that it is official and that it has been lawfully placed by the proper authority. 
(Code 1997, § 9-1-115; Ord. No. 74-9, § 1(16), 6-20-1974)  
Sec. 28-65. - Projections from the rear of vehicles. 
Whenever the load or any projecting portion of any vehicle shall extend beyond the rear of the bed or body thereof, the operator shall display at the end of such load or projection, in such position as to be clearly visible from the rear of such vehicle, a red flag being not less than 12 inches square. Between one-half hour after sunset and one-half hour before sunrise, there shall be displayed in place of a red flag a red light plainly visible under normal atmospheric conditions at least 200 feet from the rear of the vehicle. 
(Code 1997, § 9-1-116; Ord. No. 74-9, § 1(23), 6-20-1974)  
Sec. 28-66. - Reckless driving; careless or negligent driving. 
Irrespective of the posted speed limit, no person, including operators of emergency vehicles, shall drive any vehicle in willful or wanton disregard for the safety of persons or property, and such driving shall constitute the offense of reckless driving. No person shall operate a vehicle in a careless or negligent manner disregarding sensible and accepted standards of safe driving, and to do so shall constitute the offense of careless driving. 
(Code 1997, § 9-1-117; Ord. No. 74-9, § 1(9), 6-20-1974)  
Sec. 28-67. - Riding on outside of vehicles. 
No person shall ride on any portion of a vehicle not intended for the use of passengers. No driver shall allow any person to ride on any portion of the vehicle which was not intended for the use of passengers. This section shall not apply to persons riding in the load-carrying space of trucks. 
(Code 1997, § 9-1-118; Ord. No. 74-9, § 1(21), 6-20-1974)  
Sec. 28-68. - Running over fire hoses. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to drive over any hose or other equipment of the fire department except in obedience to directions of a firefighter or police officer. 
(Code 1997, § 9-1-119; Ord. No. 74-9, § 1(5), 6-20-1974) 
State Law reference Fire hoses, T.C.A. § 55-8-169.  
Sec. 28-69. - School safety patrols. 
All motorists and pedestrians shall obey the directions or signals of school safety patrols when such patrols are assigned under the authority of the chief of police and are acting in accordance with instructions, provided that such persons giving any order, signal, or direction shall at the time be wearing some insignia or using authorized flags for giving signals. 
(Code 1997, § 9-1-120; Ord. No. 74-9, § 1(17), 6-20-1974)  
Sec. 28-70. - Soliciting on right-of way. 
Solicitation of funds, loitering, impeding the flow of vehicular traffic or passing out materials on the paved portions of public roadways or on the gravel shoulder within three feet of pavement is prohibited. 
(Code 1997, § 9-1-121; Ord. No. 93-22, 10-4-1993)  
Sec. 28-71. - Streets marked with lanes. 
(a)  On streets marked with traffic lanes, it shall be unlawful for the operator of any vehicle to fail or refuse to keep his vehicle within the boundaries of the proper lane for his direction of travel except when lawfully passing another vehicle or preparing to make a turning movement. 
(b)  On two-lane or three-lane streets, the proper land for travel shall be the righthand lane unless otherwise clearly marked. On streets with four or more lanes, either of the righthand lanes shall be available for use except that traffic moving at less than the rate of speed of other vehicles shall use the extreme righthand lane. 
(Code 1997, § 9-1-122; Ord. No. 74-9, § 1(11), 6-20-1974)  
Sec. 28-72. - Streets without marked lanes. 
(a)  Upon all streets not marked with lanes, a vehicle shall be driven on the right half of the street except: 
(1)  When lawfully overtaking and passing another vehicle proceeding in the same direction. 
(2)  When the right half of a roadway is closed to traffic while under construction or repair. 
(b)  Persons driving at less than the speed of other vehicles traveling in the same direction shall drive as close to the right margin of the road as is practical except when passing or turning left. 
(Code 1997, § 9-1-123; Ord. No. 74-9, § 1(10), 6-20-1974)  
Sec. 28-73. - Unauthorized traffic control signs, etc. 
No person shall place, maintain, or display upon or in view of any street any unauthorized sign, signal, marking, or device which purports to be or is an imitation of or resembles an official traffic control sigh, signal, marking, or device or railroad sing or signal, or which attempts to control the movement of traffic or parking of vehicles, or which hides from view or interferes with the effectiveness of any official traffic control sigh, signal, marking, or device or any railroad sign or signal. 
(Code 1997, § 9-1-124; Ord. No. 74-9, § 1(15), 6-20-1974)  
Sec. 28-74. - Vehicles shortcutting through private property. 
No person shall drive a vehicle from the public roadway across private property to another portion of the public roadway to avoid an intersection or to avoid traffic that is backed up on the public roadway. This provision shall not apply to the owner of the property so crossed or to persons bearing written authorization by the property owner to cross their property. It shall be presumed that the vehicle operator is not merely trying to avoid traffic or a traffic control device if he stops the vehicle and shops or does business on the property. It shall be presumed that the driver of the vehicle is trying to avoid a traffic control device or avoid traffic and violating this Code if he drives directly through private property without stopping or exiting the vehicle. 
(Code 1997, § 9-1-126)  
Sec. 28-75. - Yellow lines. 
On streets with a yellow line placed to the right of any land line or center line, such yellow line shall designate a no-passing zone, and no operator shall drive a vehicle or any part thereof across or to the left of such yellow line except when necessary to make a lawful left turn from such street. 
(Code 1997, § 9-1-127; Ord. No. 74-9, § 1(12), 6-20-1974)  
Sec. 28-76. - Obstructing of the flow of traffic. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful to obstruct the flow of vehicular traffic on streets or public highways within the city without first providing notice to the city chief of police the intent to do so, which notice shall include the date, time and probable length of duration of said obstruction and a description of the project. 
(b)  Any such obstruction of the flow of traffic shall be supervised and regulated by an officer assigned by the city police department to such project after review of such project and traffic flow issues and or obstructions by the chief of police or his designee. Once the traffic project/plan has been reviewed and a needs assessment conducted, the chief of police or his designee will determine if an officer is necessary or if other means of traffic control will be appropriate. If the needs assessment determines that an officer is necessary, the contractor/developer or other responsible party will be directed to contact the office of secondary employment and arrange for the use of an officer at the contractor/developer's or other responsible party's cost. 
(Code 1997, § 9-1-128; Ord. No. 2003-57, 12-22-2003)  
Sec. 28-77. - Bicycle lanes. 
(a)  Every person operating a motor vehicle shall yield the right-of-way to a person operating a bicycle within a bicycle lane. A person operating a motor vehicle may cross a bicycle lane when making a turn or when entering or leaving the roadway, but a bicycle lane shall not be used as turning lane or passing lane. 
(b)  Motor vehicles should not be parked, stopped or left standing in bicycle lanes unless there is an emergency circumstance. 
(c)  A person operating a bicycle within a bicycle lane shall give an audible signal when passing another person operating a bicycle proceeding in the same direction and shall further pass on the left. 
(d)  A person operating a bicycle entering a bicycle lane shall yield the right-of-way to all bicycles in the bicycle lane. A person operating a bicycle leaving a bicycle lane shall yield the right-of-way to all vehicles and pedestrians. No person operating a bicycle lane shall leave it until the movement can be made with reasonable safety and, if any vehicle would be affected by the movement, by giving an appropriate signal before the movement is made. 
(e)  A person operating a bicycle within a bicycle lane shall travel in the same direction as motor vehicles traveling in the adjacent traffic lane. 
(Ord. No. 2018-06, § 1, 2-12-2018)  
Sec. 28-7828-95. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IV. - SPEED LIMITS 
 
Sec. 28-96. - Unposted streets have 25 mph limit. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to operate or drive a motor vehicle upon any highway or street at a rate of speed in excess of 25 miles per hour except where official signs have been posted indicating other speed limits, in which case the posted speed limits shall apply. 
(Code 1997, § 9-2-101; Ord. No. 73-10, § 1, 10-11-1973; Ord. No. 00-25, 1-8-2000)  
Sec. 28-97. - Intersections. 
No person shall drive a motor vehicle through any intersection at a rate of speed in excess of 15 miles per hour unless such person is driving on a street regulated by traffic control signals or signs which require traffic to stop or yield on the intersecting street. 
(Code 1997, § 9-2-102; Ord. No. 73-10, § 2, 10-11-1973)  
Sec. 28-98. - School zones school property. 
Unless otherwise posted, the speed limit in school zones shall be 15 miles per hour during a period of 40 minutes before school and a period of 40 minutes after school adjourns. Driving in excess of the posted limit or in excess of 15 miles per hour if not posted at a time when children are actually going to or leaving school shall be prima facie evidence of reckless driving in T.C.A. § 55-8-152. It shall be unlawful to drive in excess of 15 miles per hour on school grounds at any time. It shall be unlawful to disobey traffic control signs erected on school property. 
(Code 1997, § 9-2-103)  
Sec. 28-99. - Congested areas. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to operate or drive a motor vehicle through any congested area at a rate of speed in excess of any posted speed limit. 
(Code 1997, § 9-2-104; Ord. No. 73-10, § 4, 10-11-1973)  
Secs. 28-10028-126. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE V. - TURNING MOVEMENTS 
 
Sec. 28-127. - Operator must make turn safely and signal intention. 
No person operating a motor vehicle shall make any turning movement, which might affect any pedestrian or the operation of any other vehicle, without first ascertaining that such movement can be made in safety and without signaling his intention. 
(Code 1997, § 9-3-101; Ord. No. 74-9, § 1, 6-20-1974) 
State Law reference Similar, T.C.A. § 55-8-143.  
Sec. 28-128. - Right turns. 
Both the approach for a right turn and a right turn shall be made as close as practicable to the righthand curb or edge of the roadway. 
(Code 1997, § 9-3-102; Ord. No. 74-9, § 2(2), 6-20-1974)  
Sec. 28-129. - Left turns on two-way roadways. 
At any intersection where traffic is permitted to move in both directions on each roadway entering the intersection, an approach of a left turn shall be made in that portion of the right half of the roadway nearest the center line thereof and by passing to the right of the intersection of the center lines of the two roadways. 
(Code 1997, § 9-3-103; Ord. No. 74-9, § 2(3), 6-20-1974)  
Sec. 28-130. - Left turns on other than two-way roadways. 
At any intersection where traffic is restricted to one direction on one or more of the roadways, the driver of a vehicle intending to turn left at any such intersection shall approach the intersection in the extreme lefthand land lawfully available to traffic moving in the direction of travel of such vehicle, and after entering the intersection the left turn shall be made so as to leave the intersection, as nearly as practicable, in the lefthand lane lawfully available to traffic moving in such direction upon the roadway being entered. 
(Code 1997, § 9-3-104; Ord. No. 74-9, § 2(4), 6-20-1974)  
Sec. 28-131. - U-turns. 
U-turns are prohibited. 
(Code 1997, § 9-3-105; Ord. No. 74-9, § 2(5), 6-20-1974)  
Secs. 28-13228-160. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VI. - STOPPING AND YIELDING 
 
Sec. 28-161. - Approach of emergency vehicles. 
Upon the immediate approach of an emergency vehicle making use of audible or visual signals or of a police vehicle making use of an audible signal, the driver of every other vehicle shall immediately drive to a position parallel to, and as close as possible to, the righthand edge or curb of the roadway clear of any intersection and shall stop and remain in such position until the emergency vehicle has passed. 
(Code 1997, § 9-4-101; Ord. No. 74-9, § 3(1), 6-20-1974)  
Sec. 28-162. - Emerging from alleys, etc. 
The drivers of all vehicles emerging from alleys, parking lots, driveways, or buildings shall stop such vehicles immediately prior to driving onto any sidewalk or street. They shall not proceed to drive onto the sidewalk or street until they can safely do so without colliding or interfering with approaching pedestrians or vehicles. 
(Code 1997, § 9-4-102; Ord. No. 74-9, § 3(2), 6-20-1974)  
Sec. 28-163. - Prevent obstruction of an intersection. 
No driver shall enter any intersection or marked crosswalk unless there is sufficient space on the other side of such intersection or crosswalk to accommodate the vehicle he is operating without obstructing the passage of traffic in or on the intersecting street or crosswalk. This provision shall be effective notwithstanding any traffic control signal indication to proceed. 
(Code 1997, § 9-4-103; Ord. No. 74-9, § 3(3), 6-20-1974)  
Sec. 28-164. - Railroad crossings. 
Any driver of a vehicle approaching a railroad grade crossing shall stop at least 15 feet from the nearest rail of such railroad and shall not proceed further while any of the following conditions exist: 
(1)  A clearly visible electrical or mechanical signal device gives warning of the approach of a railroad train. 
(2)  A crossing gate is lowered or a human flagman signals the approach of a railroad train. 
(3)  A railroad train is approaching within 1,500 feet of the highway crossing and is emitting an audible signal indicating its approach or is visible and in hazardous proximity to the crossing. 
(Code 1997, § 9-4-104; Ord. No. 74-9, § 3(4), 6-20-1974)  
Sec. 28-165. - Stop signs. 
The driver of a vehicle facing a stop sign shall bring his vehicle to a complete stop immediately before entering the crosswalk on the near side of the intersection or, if there is no crosswalk, then immediately before entering the intersection, and shall remain standing until he can proceed through the intersection in safety. 
(Code 1997, § 9-4-105; Ord. No. 74-9, § 3(5), 6-20-1974)  
Sec. 28-166. - Yield signs. 
The driver of all vehicles shall yield the right-of-way to approaching vehicles before proceeding at all places where yield signs have been posted. 
(Code 1997, § 9-4-106; Ord. No. 74-9, § 3(6), 6-20-1974)  
Sec. 28-167. - Traffic control signals. 
Traffic control signals exhibiting the words "go," "caution," or "stop," or exhibiting different colored lights successively one at a time, or with arrows, shall show the following colors only and shall apply to drivers of vehicles and pedestrians as follows: 
(1)  Green alone (go signal). 
a.  Vehicular traffic facing the signal may proceed straight through or turn right or left unless a sign prohibits a movement. Vehicular traffic shall yield the right-of-way to other vehicles and to pedestrians within the intersection at the time the signal is exhibited. 
b.  Pedestrians facing the signal may proceed across the roadway within any marked or unmarked crosswalk. 
(2)  Steady yellow alone (caution signal). 
a.  A yellow signal is a warning that the red or stop signal will be soon exhibited. 
b.  Pedestrians facing such signal shall not enter the roadway. 
(3)  Steady red alone (stop signal). 
a.  Vehicular traffic facing a red signal shall stop before entering the crosswalk or the intersection. Vehicles may turn right on red if the turn can be made safely and is not prohibited by a sign. Vehicles may not cross or turn left on a red signal. 
b.  Pedestrians facing such signal shall not enter the roadway. 
(4)  Steady red with green arrows. 
a.  Vehicular traffic facing a red signal with a green arrow may cautiously enter the intersection only to make the movement indicated by the arrow, but shall yield the right-of-way to pedestrians lawfully within a crosswalk and to other traffic using the intersection. 
b.  Pedestrians facing such signal shall not enter the roadway. 
(5)  Nonintersections. If an official traffic control signal is erected other than at an intersection, this section shall also apply. Any stop shall be at least a vehicle length short of the signal. 
(Code 1997, § 9-4-107)  
Sec. 28-168. - Flashing traffic control signals. 
Drivers of vehicles shall obey illuminated flashing red or yellow traffic control signals as follows: 
(1)  Flashing red (stop signals). When a red lens is illuminated with intermittent flashes, drivers of vehicles shall stop before entering the crosswalk or intersection and the right to proceed shall be subject to the rules applicable after making a stop at stop sign. 
(2)  Flashing yellow (caution signal). When a yellow lens is illuminated with intermittent flashes, drivers of vehicles may proceed through the intersection or past such signal only with caution. 
(Code 1997, § 9-4-108)  
Sec. 28-169. - Stops to be signaled. 
All drivers shall signal their intent to stop, pursuant to T.C.A. § 55-8-143. 
(Code 1997, § 9-4-109)  
Secs. 28-17028-191. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VII. - PARKING 
 
Sec. 28-192. - Penalties. 
The total parking fine, including court costs, for any violation of any part of this article shall be $20.00. 
(Code 1997, § 9-5-120; Ord. No. 2003-53, § 3, 12-8-2003)  
Sec. 28-193. - Regulations. 
Except as otherwise provided in this section, no person shall leave any vehicle or trailer or other conveyance parked on any public street or alley between the hours of 1:00 a.m. and 5:00 a.m. Notwithstanding the foregoing, temporary permits for overnight parking may be issued by the chief of police, upon application, for extraordinary and temporary circumstances. Further, the city traffic commission may exempt individual streets or alleys, or sections of streets or alleys, from the prohibition against parking between the hours of 1:00 a.m. and 5:00 a.m. when such a request is made by the affected homeowners or the applicable homeowners association and upon a showing that such an exemption will not unreasonably impede safe traffic flow or otherwise create an unsafe condition. Vehicles or trailers found parked on any nonexempt public street or alley between 1:00 a.m. and 5:00 a.m. without a temporary permit will be ticketed. Vehicles that are parked in such a way as to cause an obstruction or hazard to normal traffic flow will be towed, with all towing and storage costs charged to the owner. 
(Code 1997, § 9-5-101; Ord. No. 2003-53, § 2, 12-8-2003; Ord. No. 2008-47, § 1, 8-11-2008)  
Sec. 28-194. - Angle parking. 
On those streets which have been signed or marked by the city for angle parking, no person shall park or stand a vehicle other than at the angle indicated by such signs or markings. No person shall angle park any vehicle which has a trailer attached thereto or which has a length in excess of 24 feet. 
(Code 1997, § 9-5-102)  
Sec. 28-195. - Occupancy of more than one space. 
No person shall park a vehicle in any designated parking space so that any part of such vehicle occupies more than one space or protrudes beyond the official markings on the street or curb designating such space unless the vehicle is too large to park within a single designated space. 
(Code 1997, § 9-5-103)  
Sec. 28-196. - Prohibited parking. 
No person shall park a vehicle in violation of any sign placed or erected by the state or city or in the following locations: 
(1)  On a sidewalk. 
(2)  In front of a public or private driveway. 
(3)  Within or within 15 feet of an intersection. 
(4)  Within 15 feet of a fire hydrant. 
(5)  Within a pedestrian crosswalk. 
(6)  Within 50 feet of a railroad crossing. 
(7)  Within 20 feet of the driveway and on the opposite side of the street of the driveway entrance to any fire station; and within 75 feet of the entrance to the fire station. 
(8)  Alongside or opposite any street excavation or obstruction when other traffic would be obstructed. 
(9)  On the roadway side of any vehicle stopped or parked at the edge or curb of a street. 
(10)  Upon any bridge. 
(11)  Alongside any curb painted yellow or red by the city. 
(Code 1997, § 9-5-104)  
Sec. 28-197. - Loading and unloading zones. 
No person shall park a vehicle for any purpose or period of time other than for the expeditious loading or unloading of passengers or merchandise in any place marked by the city as a loading and unloading zone. 
(Code 1997, § 9-5-105)  
Sec. 28-198. - Presumptions with respect to illegal parking. 
When any unoccupied vehicle is found parked in violation of any provision of this article, there shall be a prima facie presumption that the registered owner of the vehicle is responsible for such illegal parking. 
(Code 1997, § 9-5-106)  
Secs. 28-19928-220. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VIII. - ENFORCEMENT 
 
Sec. 28-221. - Failure to obey citation. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to violate a written promise to appear in court. 
(Code 1997, § 9-6-102)  
Sec. 28-222. - Illegal parking. 
(a)  Whenever any motor vehicle without a driver is found parked or stopped in violation of any of the restrictions of this Code, the officer finding the vehicle shall take its license number and may take any other information displayed on the vehicle which may identify its user and shall conspicuously affix to the vehicle a citation for the driver and owner to answer the violation at a place and time specified in the citation. 
(b)  Parking violations involving disabled person spaces, fire lanes, obstructing traffic, parking near a fire hydrant and parking providing a danger to the public shall be punished by a fine in an amount set by the city judge not to exceed $500.00. For other parking violations which present no danger to the public, the defendant may waive a hearing and pay a fine of $10.00 if paid prior to the court date; otherwise the fine will be the amount set by the city judge. 
(Code 1997, § 9-6-103)  
Sec. 28-223. - Impoundment of vehicles. 
(a)  Police officers are authorized, when reasonably necessary to prevent the obstruction of traffic to remove from the streets and impound any vehicle: 
(1)  Whose operator is arrested; 
(2)  Which is illegally parked or abandoned; or 
(3)  Which is an obstruction or hazard to normal traffic. 
(b)  Any vehicle left parked on any street or alley for more than 72 consecutive hours without permission from the chief of police shall be presumed to have been abandoned, if the owner cannot be located after a reasonable investigation. 
(c)  An impounded vehicle shall be stored until: 
(1)  The owner claims it; 
(2)  Gives satisfactory evidence of ownership; and 
(3)  Pays all applicable fines and costs. 
(d)  The fee for impounding a vehicle shall be $25.00 and all wrecker charges and a storage cost of $10.00 per day if stored by the city. If stored at a private storage facility, the storage cost shall be the charge of the private facility. 
(Code 1997, § 9-6-104)  
Sec. 28-224. - Automated traffic enforcement. 
(a)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning. 
Citations and warning notices includes: 
(1)  The name and address of the registered owner of the vehicle; 
(2)  The registration plate number of the motor vehicle involved in the violation; 
(3)  The violation charged; 
(4)  The location of the violation; 
(5)  The date and time of the violation; 
(6)  A copy of the recorded images; 
(7)  The amount of the civil penalty imposed and the date by which the civil penalty should be paid; 
(8)  A signed statement by a member of the city police department that, based on inspection of recorded images, the motor vehicle was being operated in violation of subsection (c) of this section; 
(9)  A statement that recorded images are evidence of a violation of this chapter; and 
(10)  Information advising the person alleged to be liable under this section: 
a.  Of the manner and time in which liability alleged in the citation occurred and that the citation may be contested in city court; and 
b.  Warning that failure to contest in the manner and time provided shall be deemed an admission of liability and that a default judgment may be entered thereon. 
In operation means operating in good working condition. 
Recorded images means images recorded by a traffic control photographic system showing the rear of a motor vehicle and, on at least one image or portion of tape, clearly identifying the registration number of the motor vehicle on the following: 
(1)  Two or more photographs; 
(2)  Two or more microphotographs; 
(3)  Two or more electronic images; 
(4)  Videotape; or 
(5)  Any other medium. 
Stop line means a transverse white marking at an approach to an intersection that indicates a point behind which all vehicles must stop when so required by a traffic control sign, signal or device. 
System location means the approach to an intersection toward which a photographic, video or electronic camera is directed and is in operation. 
Traffic control photographic system means an electronic system consisting of a photographic, video or electronic camera and a vehicle sensor installed to work in conjunction with an official traffic control sign, signal or device, and to automatically produce photographs, video or digital images of each vehicle violating a standard traffic control sign, signal or device. 
Vehicle owner means the person identified by the state department of safety as the registered owner of a vehicle or a lessee of a motor vehicle under a lease of six months or more. 
(b)  General. 
(1)  The police department or an agent of the department shall administer the traffic control photographic systems and shall maintain a list of system locations where traffic control photographic systems are installed. 
(2)  Any citation or warning for a violation of this chapter issued by an officer of the police department at a system location shall be treated in the manner prescribed in this article. 
(3)  The city shall adopt procedures for the issuance of citations. A citation or warning alleging that the violation of subsection (c) of this section occurred, sworn to or affirmed by a law enforcement officer of the city, based on inspection of recorded images produced by a traffic control photographic system, shall be evidence of the facts contained therein and shall be admissible in any proceeding alleging a violation under this section. The citation or warning shall be forwarded by first class mail to the vehicle owner's address as given on the motor vehicle registration. Personal service of process on the vehicle owner shall not be required. 
(4)  Signs to indicate the use of traffic control photographic systems shall be posted in advance of individual system locations and may be posted elsewhere in the city. 
(c)  Offense. 
(1)  It shall be unlawful for a vehicle to cross the stop line at a system location or for a vehicle to violate any other traffic regulation specified in this chapter. 
(2)  A person who receives a citation or warning under subsection (c) of this section may: 
a.  Pay the civil penalty, in accordance with the instructions on the citation or warning, directly to city court; or 
b.  Elect to contest the citation for the alleged violation. 
(3)  The owner of a vehicle shall be responsible for a violation under this section, except when such owner can provide evidence that the vehicle was in the care, custody or control of another person at the time of the violation, as described in subsection (c)(4) of this section, in which circumstance the person who had the care, custody and control of the vehicle at the time of the violation shall be responsible. 
(4)  Notwithstanding this subsection, the owner of the vehicle shall not be responsible for the violation if, within 30 days of mailing of such citation, such owner furnishes the city court an affidavit, by said owner, stating: 
a.  The name and address of the person or entity who leased, rented or otherwise had the care, custody and control of the vehicle at the time of the violation; or 
b.  The vehicle or its registration plates were stolen at the time of the alleged violation and the registered owner was not operating the vehicle. In order to demonstrate that the motor vehicle or the registration plates were stolen before the violation occurred and were not under the control or possession of the owner at the time of the violation, the owner must submit a certified copy of the police report concerning the stolen motor vehicle or registration plates. 
(5)  If the person named in the citation is an owner of a commercial vehicle with a registered gross weight of 10,000 pounds or more, a tractor vehicle, a trailer operated in combination with a tractor vehicle or a passenger bus, in order to demonstrate that said owner was not the violator that person shall, in a letter mailed to city court by certified mail, return receipt requested: 
a.  Swear that the person named in the citation was not operating the vehicle at the time of the violation; and 
b.  Provide the name, address and driver's license identification number of the person who was operating the vehicle at the time of the violation. 
(d)  Penalty.
